resumen: La incertidumbre de la pol√≠tica comercial estadounidense y los posibles escenarios de variaci√≥n de precios han llevado a la Reserva Federal, encabezada por Jerome Powell, a mantener por m√°s tiempo una postura monetaria restrictiva. La tasa de desocupaci√≥n de mayo se mantuvo en un 4.2%. En dicho mes se crearon 139 mil puestos de trabajo y la tasa de inflaci√≥n, medida por la variaci√≥n relativa del √çndice de Precios de Gastos de Consumo Personal, se coloc√≥ en abril en un 2.1%. Los pron√≥sticos del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) son negativos. Gita Gopinath, primera subdirectora gerente de dicha instituci√≥n, indic√≥ que los altos aranceles reducir√°n la tasa de crecimiento mundial en, por lo menos, medio punto porcentual y que, en algunos pa√≠ses, como Estados Unidos, podr√≠a aumentar de manera significativa la tasa de inflaci√≥n. Se prev√© que la tasa de inter√©s de referencia seguir√° inalterada hasta la reuni√≥n de septiembre. La doctora Gopinath, quien fue profesora en el Departamento de Econom√≠a de la Universidad de Harvard, advierte que las condiciones financieras restrictivas podr√≠an afectar de manera desfavorable los flujos de capitales que se dirigen hacia las econom√≠as emergentes. La transmisi√≥n de la pol√≠tica monetaria de los pa√≠ses emergentes depende de las condiciones financieras externas, relacionadas con la pol√≠tica monetaria estadounidense y con el acceso al financiamiento del mercado de capitales a trav√©s de la colocaci√≥n de bonos soberanos. En la Rep√∫blica Dominicana, entre mayo de 2023 y enero de 2025, el Banco Central inyect√≥ una masiva cantidad de liquidez y redujo la tasa de inter√©s de pol√≠tica monetaria en 275 puntos b√°sicos, hasta llevarla al 5.75%; sin embargo, la tasa pasiva solo baj√≥ 81 puntos b√°sicos y la tasa activa apenas disminuy√≥ 69 puntos b√°sicos. La Reserva Federal solo redujo su tasa de inter√©s de referencia en 75 puntos b√°sicos y qued√≥ en el rango que va del 4.25% al 4.5%. La pol√≠tica monetaria de Estados Unidos es un determinante fundamental de las tasas de inter√©s del mercado financiero dominicano y, por tanto, del ritmo de crecimiento del producto interno bruto (PIB). La pol√≠tica monetaria de las econom√≠as emergentes tiene menor capacidad de mantener ancladas las expectativas de inflaci√≥n. Para fortalecer la confianza de los agentes econ√≥micos, es importante que no haya interferencias pol√≠ticas en las decisiones del banco central y mucho menos dominancia fiscal, a fin de evitar un financiamiento del d√©ficit del sector p√∫blico a trav√©s de emisi√≥n monetaria. Es esencial que los bancos centrales respondan con rapidez y firmeza ante los riesgos inflacionarios provenientes del exterior y eviten que la variaci√≥n de precios se incruste en las expectativas, mediante mecanismos de indexaci√≥n que acent√∫en la persistencia de la inflaci√≥n. El Banco Central de la Rep√∫blica Dominicana ha logrado preservar el anclaje de las expectativas de inflaci√≥n. Una parte de ese resultado se explica por el subsidio de los precios de los combustibles y de la tarifa el√©ctrica. La subdirectora gerente de FMI sostiene que, a pesar de que en muchas econom√≠as emergentes el efecto de las variaciones cambiarias sobre la inflaci√≥n ha disminuido, sigue siendo significativo en comparaci√≥n con lo que ocurre en las econom√≠as avanzadas. Se estima que, en los pa√≠ses en desarrollo, por cada 1% de depreciaci√≥n de la moneda nacional respecto al d√≥lar, los precios suben un 0.2%. Gopinath aconseja que la intervenci√≥n en el mercado cambiario se lleve a cabo con cautela y solo cuando sea realmente necesario, como en situaciones de salida abrupta de capitales o de ataques especulativos contra la moneda. La adopci√≥n de un esquema de metas de inflaci√≥n en la Rep√∫blica Dominicana en 2012 ha reducido el efecto de transmisi√≥n del tipo de cambio a los precios. Las autoridades dominicanas podr√≠an fortalecer dicho esquema mediante una comunicaci√≥n m√°s transparente y efectiva de sus decisiones de pol√≠tica monetaria. Para asegurar el buen funcionamiento del marco de metas de inflaci√≥n es imprescindible evitar la adopci√≥n de medidas monetarias zigzagueantes, sub√≥ptimas e inconsistentes.

title: U.S. and China to Meet at Precarious Moment in Trade War
content: Officials from both sides are set to talk on Monday in London, aiming to resolve differences over tariffs and supply chains that have endangered a fragile truce between the countries.
resumen:
Top officials from the Trump administration will meet with their Chinese counterparts in London on Monday for a second round of economic talks.

The American delegation will be led by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Jamieson Greer, the United States‚Äô trade representative.

China will be represented by He Lifeng, the country‚Äôs vice premier for economic policy.

The meetings are expected to run through Tuesday.

In April, the United States paused some of the tariffs that Mr. Trump imposed on dozens of countries to provide time for trade negotiations.

In late May, a U.S. trade court deemed the tariffs illegal. The tariffs, however, remain in place while an appeal process unfolds.

The Trump administration faces a deadline to make its case to a federal appeals court for why the tariffs should continue.

China on Monday reported that shipments to the United States fell by over 34 percent in May from the same month a year ago.

The first round of negotiations between China and the United States, in Geneva last month, ended with promise. The countries agreed to temporarily reduce their tariffs, which exceeded 100 percent.

The two sides also agreed to hold additional talks as they worked to lower the temperature.

China maintained strict curbs on exports of rare earth magnets.

The Trump administration suspended sales to China of technologies related to jet engines, semiconductors and certain chemicals and machinery as well as proposed a plan to revoke visas for Chinese students associated with the Communist Party or studying in certain fields.

A 90-minute conversation between Mr. Trump and Xi Jinping, China‚Äôs leader, this week appeared to ease the tension.

The addition to the U.S. delegation of Mr. Lutnick, who was not part of the talks in May, suggested that there could be greater discussion of American export controls, which his agency oversees.

The Trump administration also expressed concerns about China‚Äôs currency practices in a report to Congress this week.

Many factories in the United States, Europe and Japan are quickly running out of rare earth magnets, for which China produces 90 percent of the world‚Äôs supply.

Beijing announced on April 4 that it would require export licenses for all exports of seven rare earth metals and magnets made from them.

Kevin Hassett, director of the White House National Economic Council, said in an interview on CBS‚Äôs ‚ÄúFace the Nation‚Äù on Sunday that a goal of the talks would be to get shipments of rare earths from China ‚Äúto flow just as they did before the beginning of April.‚Äù

China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce said on Saturday that it had offered to speed up the approval of rare earth exports to Europe.

The ministry also called for the European Union to remove its recent tariffs on imports of electric cars from China, and it called for the bloc to allow more sales of high-tech goods to China.

The Netherlands has limited the sale to China of equipment for manufacturing the most advanced semiconductors.

title: Trump y Musk: aliados rotos, titanes enfrentados en la derecha estadounidense
content: El v√≠nculo entre Donald Trump y Elon Musk, una vez estrat√©gico, ha entrado en una peligrosa fase de ruptura. Lo que comenz√≥ como una alianza de conveniencia entre dos figuras clave del poder econ√≥mico ...

El v√≠nculo entre Donald Trump y Elon Musk ha entrado en una fase de ruptura. El enfrentamiento entre Donald Trump y Elon Musk, que en pocos d√≠as pasaron de amigos a enemigos y que corre el riesgo de transformar a los que alguna vez fueron aliados en futuros adversarios (Musk propone fundar un nuevo partido), ha llenado las portadas de los peri√≥dicos de todo el mundo.

La cuesti√≥n del conflicto deber√≠a dividirse en dos aspectos: el de la forma, muy tratado por los medios convencionales, y el de la sustancia, decididamente pasado por alto. La ruptura se produjo en el contenido de la pol√≠tica econ√≥mica y fiscal, en el papel mismo que deber√≠a desempe√±ar el multimillonario de origen sudafricano y en su peso real en la toma de decisiones.

La historia entre Donald Trump y Elon Musk llevaba desde el principio escrita su propia conclusi√≥n. Dos personajes histri√≥nicos en constante b√∫squeda de visibilidad y sin ning√∫n reparo por los da√±os colaterales que eso conlleva, dif√≠cilmente pod√≠an convivir por mucho tiempo.

And if parliament needs to sit longer, it should sit longer.‚Äù

Carney‚Äôs government had to backpedal from a campaign promise of cross-Canada free trade by Canada Day. During a technical briefing for the bill, government officials said the goal is now to remove as many internal trade barriers ‚Äúas possible‚Äù by July 1.

The Modi invite marked a remarkable shift in foreign policy for the Liberal government. Only eight months ago, the Trudeau government expelled India‚Äôs high commissioner and five envoys after the RCMP revealed evidence linking members of India‚Äôs government to multiple homicides on Canadian soil. The RCMP also uncovered apparent evidence of Indian interference into Canada‚Äôs democratic processes.

‚ÄúMy constituents are telling me it‚Äôs the wrong move to invite Prime Minister Modi,‚Äù Dhaliwal said to Playbook. ‚ÄúCanada is the country of rule of law, the country of justice, the champion of human rights.‚Äù

Dhaliwal represents the riding of Surrey Newton, where Sikh Khalistani activist HARDEEP SINGH NIJJAR was gunned down in June 2023 outside a gurdwara. He was a constituent of Dhaliwal‚Äôs.

Trudeau told the House of Commons in September 2023 that Canada had ‚Äúcredible allegations‚Äù that agents acting on behalf of the Indian government were involved in Nijjar‚Äôs death. title: Tell Me How This Trade War Ends
content: From 2019 to 2021, first in the Trump administration and then in the Biden administration, she was Deputy Assistant U.S. Trade Representative for Investment. Geoffrey Gertz is a Senior Fellow in the ...
resumen:
On April 2, President Donald Trump announced a new program of tariffs intended to rebalance U.S. trade. Trump's tariff rates were high, triggering a stock market selloff and diplomatic outrage. After a week of backlash, the president announced a 90-day pause on most tariffs. U.S. court rulings questioning the legality of the president‚Äôs tariffs have added further uncertainty.

The Trump administration‚Äôs trade policy has caused harm, slowing growth and raising prices. Distrust of free trade has been rising in both political parties in the United States. Governments around the world are more and more willing to intervene in their economies to safeguard national interests. The U.S.-led global trading order, constructed over eight decades following World War II, has frayed.

Instead of trying to turn back time, actors should push the administration to usher in the needed transformation of the global trading order. Disruptive tariffs can create an opportunity. The United States retains deep-rooted structural advantages that give it the power to lead a new trade effort. Washington can leverage its trade wars to achieve a productive restructuring of the international economic system.

The Trump administration must build a new set of rules and norms that facilitate integration among like-minded states and that disentangle them from adversarial ones, especially China.

The current trading system prioritizes nondiscrimination and the ‚Äúmost favored nation‚Äù principle. But economic and national security concerns differ by trading partner. Increasing geopolitical competition has compelled more and more countries to impose export controls, sanctions, and other economic restrictions on trading partners.

Trump has turned the United States into a revisionist power. There is still an opportunity to wrest a positive outcome from the current tumult. In March, the Center for a New American Security ran a simulation of a trade war to examine how foreign governments might respond to sharply increased U.S. tariffs. By the end of the game, the U.S. team had unexpectedly succeeded in laying the foundation for a highly integrated democratic trading bloc that shut out China.

To achieve a positive outcome, Trump will have to prioritize good-faith trade negotiations and tamp down the more chaotic aspects of his trade policy.

Washington must use tariffs as leverage in pursuit of clear and achievable trade objectives. The administration has offered an array of rationales for the tariffs. The administration was always going to have to prioritize its aims; the sooner it does so, the better.

The Trump administration can still improve U.S. credibility by bringing more order and predictability into the trade policymaking process. The administration could use instruments such as Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, which addresses unfair trade practices, and Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act, which allows the United States to impose tariffs or take other remedial actions on national security grounds. Washington must also clarify what it expects of allies.

Trump has demonstrated little interest in adopting a more deliberate, methodical approach to negotiations or to recalibrating his means to meet more achievable ends.

The United States could advance a more nakedly transactional approach in its international economic relations, eschewing any rules or shared norms that might constrain U.S. action.

Having used tariffs to shake trading partners out of their complacency, the United States can work with these countries to negotiate a reset of the trading system‚Äîone that preserves many of the advantages of the old system while rectifying its shortcomings. The starting point should be relaxing the principle of nondiscrimination and accepting that trade policy will differentiate among trade partners and allow democracies to favor one another.

The United States should continue to trade with China in low-end manufacturing, agriculture, and a handful of other areas. But in more strategic sectors, such as chips and pharmaceuticals, Trump should prioritize ‚Äúde-risking‚Äù from China. Washington should make significant investments in domestic manufacturing and research and design, coordinating with other major economies wherever possible.

Trump should aim for a future order made up of the following concentric circles: deep economic and security integration for close allies and partners; predictable, rules-based exchange among most countries; and careful de-risking from competitors. Washington should seek to establish legally binding commitments with its close partners that provide the clarity, consistency, and credibility that businesses and governments require.

title: Overcoming the geopolitics of overcapacity through cooperation
content: Multilateral reform is needed to counteract prevailing narratives of Chinese overcapacity and restore confidence in the rules-based trade system.
resumen:
Overcapacity in Chinese industries like steel, EVs and solar panels has become a flashpoint in global trade, especially in US‚ÄìChina tensions. While often framed as unfair trade practices due to subsidies and low-priced exports, these concerns reflect deeper strategic fears about China‚Äôs rise in key sectors. Lasting solutions require multilateral cooperation and WTO reform to restore trade stability.

‚ÄòOvercapacity‚Äô has become a buzzword in trade policy discussions, especially amid US‚ÄìChina trade tensions. Overcapacity is a global issue that requires multilateral cooperation and reform to address structural imbalances and restore trade stability.

The ‚ÄòChina shock‚Äô that followed China‚Äôs 2001 accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) led to massive influxes of Chinese exports into the United States and other economies.

In 2024, then treasury secretary Janet Yellen and under secretary for international affairs Jay Shambaugh criticised China for creating excessive production capacity through industrial policies and subsidies across sectors like steel, solar panels and electric vehicles (EVs).

Governments‚Äô key concerns are overcapacity‚Äôs underlying causes and spillover effects via artificially low-priced exports, widely labelled as ‚Äòunfair trade practices‚Äô, causing injury to domestic industries.

The Biden administration levied high tariffs on Chinese steel, EV and solar cells exports. US President Donald Trump‚Äôs 2025 tariffs against China target non-market policies and unfair trade practices to revitalise US manufacturing competitiveness and global leadership.

China‚Äôs innovation and sustainability-oriented development strategies have generated selective industrial policies whose spillover effects may become increasingly concentrated in strategic and emerging sectors like advanced manufacturing and frontier technologies.

Studies have found no compelling evidence of an economy-wide overcapacity problem in China and argue that China needs time to make necessary industrial adjustments given declining domestic consumption. China has contended that other countries also have overcapacity issues in certain sectors. China has also sought to reduce capacity in traditional industries like steel to facilitate industrial restructuring and sustainable development while rolling out plans to boost domestic consumption.

Criticisms of overcapacity serve more political and strategic goals than purely economic interests. China‚Äôs industrial overcapacity poses challenges for trading partners as it represents a quest for global leadership in key and emerging industries and critical supply chains.

China dominates global EV production and sales, alarming trading partners. The United States, European Union, Canada and Brazil have imposed high tariffs on Chinese EV imports.

China remains the world‚Äôs top producer and exporter of steel, solar panels and EVs despite facing high antidumping and countervailing tariffs and other restrictive measures for decades. In some cases, Chinese exporters absorbed the price increases resulting from tariffs. In other cases, Chinese firms redirected exports to or via third countries or relocated production overseas, an approach known as ‚Äòtariff circumvention‚Äô.

Many economies have developed so-called anti-circumvention instruments which extend existing tariffs to the same or similar Chinese exports from third-country markets. Beijing also sought to counteract foreign sanctions through WTO litigation and retaliatory measures.

Escalating trade restrictions ‚Äî particularly Trump‚Äôs 2025 tariffs ‚Äî have accelerated China‚Äôs pivot towards domestic economic rebalancing. China has rolled out measures to redirect excess industrial output towards the domestic market. These include expanded consumer subsidies for durable goods, tax incentives for firms repurposing export production for domestic sale and initiatives to bolster rural and middle-class spending.

Actions against Chinese overcapacity exacerbate global trade uncertainty, distort commercial decisions and disrupt global supply chains. US tariffs against China can redirect Chinese exports to other markets, ratcheting up overcapacity pressure on the rest of the world.

It is time for governments to cooperate. The US‚ÄìChina deal reached on 12 May 2025 to scale back a significant portion of their respective tariffs and establish a mechanism for cooperative talks marks a step in the right direction.

Overcapacity is a global issue that cannot be resolved unilaterally or bilaterally. It requires multilateral reforms of the rules-based international trading regime, with the WTO at its core. Overcapacity requires a detailed examination now with a particular focus on overcapacity‚Äôs underlying drivers like persistent demand shortfalls and industrial subsidies.

title: India could cut tariffs for all except China
content: India has been in Trump‚Äôs crosshairs since the start of his second term. On April 2, he proposed a 26 per cent reciprocal tariff on Indian imports, later withdrawn, but imposed a 10 per cent baseline ...
resumen: India should consider cutting tariffs for all trading partners except China. Global trade is shifting rapidly, with the US and China experiencing tariff stand-offs. The US imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on nearly all countries, including India. India has largely avoided retaliating against US tariffs, except for plans to counter US duties on Indian steel and aluminum. India should adopt a proactive, broad-based strategy, including across-the-board tariff cuts. India's average MFN tariffs are higher than many peers. Tariff cuts improve resource allocation and boost overall economic welfare. China may target India regardless of tariff cuts due to weak global demand and its own strained economy. In 2024, 25 of 31 ongoing anti-dumping investigations and 24 of 29 concluded cases involved Chinese firms. A more strategic response to Chinese dumping is to cut tariffs for all trading partners, except China. Global trade simulations were run using the GTAP dataset and model. With a 25 per cent across-the-board tariff cut, India could gain $54 billion, boost GDP by 2.6 per cent, sectoral output by 2.8 per cent, and exports by 4.3 per cent. Imports from China would surge by 8.6 per cent. Under the second policy, where tariffs on China remain unchanged, GDP, welfare, and output remain strong, domestic demand doubles, and exports stay positive. title: The EU can play it cool with Trump‚Äôs trade threats
content: Other governments have so far taken three main approaches to dealing with Donald Trump‚Äôs trade threats. China hit back hard at the U.S. president‚Äôs tariffs and got him to back down partly. Canada also ...
resumen:
Other governments have so far taken three main approaches to dealing with Donald Trump‚Äôs trade threats. China hit back hard at the U.S. president‚Äôs tariffs and got him to back down partly. Canada also retaliated and avoided some of the pain Trump inflicted on other countries. Meanwhile, Britain cut a quick deal that favoured the United States. None of these is a model for the European Union.

The EU is not China. Though its bilateral goods trade with the United States last year was worth 70% more than between the U.S. and the People‚Äôs Republic, the EU is not an autocracy that can outpunch Trump. If it antagonises the U.S. president, he might up the stakes by pulling the rug from under Ukraine and undermining the EU‚Äôs defences. American hard power gives it what geopolitical strategists call ‚Äúescalation dominance‚Äù.

The EU is not Canada either. Ottawa was able to hang tough because its people were infuriated that Trump was trying to blackmail Canada into becoming part of the United States. While anti-Trump sentiment is high in the EU, politicians who are sympathetic to him, such as Poland‚Äôs new president, can still get elected.

The EU is not the United Kingdom. Both are at risk from Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. But the EU trades seven times more goods with the United States than Britain does - so Washington has more to lose if economic relations break down.

There is another way for the EU to handle Trump‚Äôs threats: play it cool. It involves neither escalating the conflict nor accepting a bad deal. It means being open to a good agreement if the U.S. lowers its demands, but willing to play the long game if it does not.

One reason to buy time is to help Kyiv. The longer the EU has to prepare its own support package for Ukraine, which should include getting it a lot of cash, the less the damage if Trump ultimately cuts off all U.S. aid to the country.

The president‚Äôs own vulnerabilities may also increase over time. Just look at the spectacular end of his alliance with Tesla boss Elon Musk. The fragile U.S. trade truce with China may break down causing more financial turmoil, making Trump less keen to pick a fight with the EU. If the Supreme Court stops him using emergency powers to impose tariffs, his negotiating position will be weaker. And tariffs could hurt the U.S. more than its supposed victims, by pushing up inflation and crimping growth.

Trump has zig-zagged in his trade threats and actions against the EU. The current state of play is that there are 50% tariffs on U.S. imports of steel and aluminium from the bloc, a 25% tariff on cars and 10% so-called reciprocal tariffs on most other goods.

The U.S. president has threatened to jack up these reciprocal tariffs to 50% if there is no deal by July 9. He is also looking at more ‚Äúsectoral tariffs‚Äù, including on pharmaceuticals and semiconductors.

While the EU has complained to the World Trade Organization (WTO), it has delayed its own retaliation. Its negotiators accept that they are unlikely to overturn the reciprocal tariffs, the Financial Times has reported.

The bloc still aims to avoid the sectoral ones. Those on cars and any on pharmaceuticals would hurt it the most. It has dangled the possibility of buying more U.S. equipment and natural gas to get a deal.

An agreement on those lines could be good for the EU. It needs to beef up its defences and eliminate its purchases of Russian gas. While it would be best to have its own arms and energy supplies, buying more from the U.S. makes sense as an interim measure. An important nuance, though, is that the EU should reserve the right to take action against the reciprocal tariffs after the WTO issues its verdict, says Ignacio Garcia Bercero, a former senior EU trade official.

Such a pact would involve quite a climbdown by Trump. True, arms and gas purchases would narrow the U.S. goods deficit with the EU, which was $236 billion last year. But his administration has a host of other complaints including the bloc‚Äôs value-added tax and food safety standards as well the digital taxes that some of its members impose on tech giants. It is hard to see the bloc agreeing anything in those areas, says Simon Evenett, professor of geopolitics and strategy at IMD.

Although the U.S. side described last week‚Äôs trade talks with the EU as ‚Äúvery constructive‚Äù, discussions could easily break down. The question then is how the bloc would react if Trump imposed higher reciprocal tariffs.

The EU has so far imposed no countermeasures. Though it has agreed to tax 21 billion euros of U.S. imports in response to the steel and aluminium tariffs, it has delayed these until July 14 to try to get a deal. The European Commission, its executive arm, is also consulting on taxing a further 95 billion euros of U.S. imports in response to the car tariffs and the reciprocal ones. But added together, these tit-for-tat measures would be equivalent to only a third of the 379 billion euros of EU imports subject to Trump‚Äôs tariffs.

Some analysts think the bloc needs to be tougher. One idea is to crack down on American services, where the U.S. had a 109 billion euro surplus with the EU in 2023. Another is to activate its ‚Äúanti-coercion instrument‚Äù, which would allow retaliation against U.S. companies operating in the bloc. Yet another is to threaten to ban exports of critical goods, such as the lithographic equipment necessary to make semiconductors.

For now, the EU should keep its cool. It should not kid itself that it is stronger or more united than it is. It should remember that Trump may get weaker with time. And it should never forget Ukraine.

title: US aluminium tariffs threaten scrap clash with European Union
content: U.S. President Donald Trump's move to double tariffs on aluminium imports heightens the risk of a full-blown scrap war with the European Union.
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump's move to double tariffs on aluminium imports heightens the risk of a full-blown scrap war with the European Union. Aluminium scrap is explicitly excluded on the grounds it constitutes a key raw material for U.S. manufacturers. The Trump administration's decision to lift aluminium tariffs to 25% effective the start of March has already caused U.S. imports of recyclable material to rise. This week's doubling of the tariff rate to 50% could turn the import flow into a flood. The European Union, which is mulling export duties on aluminium recyclables to stop what it terms "scrap leakage", is coming under pressure to move sooner rather than later. The U.S. Midwest aluminium premium has rocketed to a record $1,325 per metric ton after Wednesday's doubling-down on import tariffs. That's the price U.S. buyers will pay over and above the international price traded on the London Metal Exchange (LME), currently $2,430 per ton for cash metal. U.S. consumers of aluminium goods will ultimately foot the bill but mid-stream processors are likely to do well. U.S. imports of aluminium recyclable materials jumped to over 80,000 tons in March, the highest monthly volume since 2022. There were sharp increases in supply from Canada and Mexico. Exports from EU countries to the United States spiked in the first quarter of the year. The EU is facing a "full-blown scrap crisis". Director General Paul Voss called on the European Commission to immediately impose a corresponding duty on scrap exports to the United States. A March "Action Plan" for both the aluminium and steel sectors promised a decision by the third quarter of this year on suitable trade measures, including reciprocal export tariffs on countries "that apply unfair subsidies" to their recycling industries. Caught in the middle of this tug-of-war is China, the world's largest aluminium scrap buyer. The country has imported 1.8 million tons in each of the last two years. Beijing last year relaxed the purity rules on imports of both copper and aluminium scrap to encourage greater domestic recycling.

title: Trump's trade war is raising money for the government, but at whose expense?
content: Tariff collections are up sharply in the last 2 months. Congressional forecasters say tariffs could help reduce the federal debt, but they'll also lead to higher inflation and slower economic growth.
resumen: President Trump's tariffs are helping the government's bottom line. The federal government collected $68.9 billion in tariffs and excise taxes during the first five months of the year, according to Treasury Department data collected by the Bipartisan Policy Center. This is a 78% increase from the same period a year ago. Much of the additional revenue came in April and May, after Trump imposed tariffs of at least 10% on nearly everything the U.S. buys from other countries. The tariffs are mostly being paid by American businesses and families. Patrick Allen, a Columbus, Ohio-based importer who sells French wine throughout the country, says, "It's a tax on the backs of people who are importing either raw materials or, in my case, wine." The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projected that if Trump's tariffs were to remain in place for a full decade, they could shave $2.8 trillion off the federal debt. The CBO also acknowledged that the tariffs will result in higher inflation this year and next, as well as slower economic growth. A survey from the Institute for Supply Management suggests tariffs are a substantial drag on the manufacturing sector, which cut 8,000 jobs last month. resumen: PANDORA, the world‚Äôs largest jewellery company, is based in Denmark and has nearly 500 stores in the United States. Its products have been made in Thailand for nearly four decades. In April, US President Donald Trump said he would impose 36% tariffs on goods entering the United States from Thailand. After Trump unveiled his ‚Äúreciprocal tariffs‚Äù, Pandora‚Äôs shares were among the worst performing in Europe. Trump postponed those tariffs until early July. Alexander Lacik, CEO of Pandora, is not expecting the uncertainty to end. Unless tariffs return to previous levels, the next year will be turbulent. Lacik says he is not expecting the uncertainty paralysing businesses to end unless tariffs returned to previous levels. Pandora has been making jewellery in Thailand since 1989. Across three factories, thousands of people handcraft the products. The company is building a fourth plant in Vietnam, but Trump has also threatened tariffs on Vietnamese goods. Last year, the company sold 113 million pieces of jewellery, about three items every second, making it the largest jewellery brand by volume, with stores in more than 100 countries. A third of Pandora‚Äôs sales, US$1.4bil, was generated in the United States. Prices will rise, and who will bear the brunt of that is unclear. Pandora keeps several months‚Äô worth of stock. The day after the reciprocal tariffs were announced, Pandora said that it would change its distribution so that products sold in Canada and Latin America would no longer move through the company‚Äôs distribution hub in Baltimore, a process that would take six to nine months to complete. Pandora employs nearly 15,000 craftspeople in Thailand and expects to hire 7,000 more in Vietnam. If higher tariffs go back into effect, they would cost Pandora US$74mil this year, and then US$135mil annually after that. When he joined the company as the CEO in 2019, Pandora was struggling. Its share price had dropped more than 70% from its peak three years earlier. In January, Pandora‚Äôs share price reached a record high. Since then, however, it has dropped more than 20%.

**June 9, 2025, 12:01 a.m. ETAlan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher**

Top officials from the Trump administration will meet with their Chinese counterparts in London on Monday for a second round of economic talks, aiming to cement a trade truce between the world‚Äôs two largest economies. The American delegation will be led by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Jamieson Greer, the United States‚Äô trade representative. China will be represented by He Lifeng, the country‚Äôs vice premier for economic policy. The meetings are expected to run through Tuesday. The talks come at a delicate juncture for the global economy, which has been slowed by uncertainty and supply chain disruptions. In April, the United States paused some of the tariffs that Mr. Trump imposed on dozens of countries to provide time for trade negotiations. Those levies, as well as steep import taxes on Chinese goods, were thrust into further uncertainty in late May, when a U.S. trade court deemed them illegal. The tariffs, however, remain in place while an appeal process unfolds. As the U.S. delegation negotiates in London, the Trump administration faces a deadline to make its case to a federal appeals court for why the tariffs should continue. The legal limbo surrounding the tariffs could weaken the Trump administration‚Äôs hand as it tries to negotiate a broader agreement to give American businesses greater access to China‚Äôs market, push Beijing to buy more American products and attract more Chinese investment to build factories in the United States. At the same time, the Trump administration wants to make some tariffs essentially permanent to discourage a flood of Chinese exports of manufactured goods. The trade war has triggered sudden and drastic shifts in the flow of Chinese goods, most notably a sharp slowdown of Chinese exports to the United States. China on Monday reported that shipments to the United States fell by over 34 percent in May from the same month a year ago, the steepest decline since 2020. In China, a slow-motion housing market collapse over the past four years has wiped out much of the savings of the country‚Äôs middle class, leaving hundreds of millions of households reluctant to spend. China has tried to offset weak consumer spending at home with a huge, government-financed campaign to build factories and ramp up exports. The Trump administration, like the Biden administration before it, has been wary that these exports could crush what is left of America‚Äôs manufacturing sector, which is only half the size of China‚Äôs. The Trump administration has cited trade imbalances as justification for tariffs against China and dozens of other countries, many of which pay for their own trade deficits with China by running large trade surpluses with the United States. The first round of negotiations between China and the United States, in Geneva last month, ended with promise. The countries agreed to temporarily reduce their tariffs, which exceeded 100 percent as a tit-for-tat trade war escalated. The two sides also agreed to hold additional talks as they worked to lower the temperature. China maintained strict curbs on exports of rare earth magnets that have crippled supply chains. Partly in response to those export curbs, among other things the Trump administration suspended sales to China of technologies related to jet engines, semiconductors and certain chemicals and machinery as well as proposed a plan to revoke visas for Chinese students associated with the Communist Party or studying in certain fields. A 90-minute conversation between Mr. Trump and Xi Jinping, China‚Äôs leader, this week appeared to ease the tension. Mr. Trump suggested that the questions surrounding China‚Äôs restrictions on critical minerals known as rare earths, and magnets made from them, had been addressed and that talks would proceed. Mr. Trump also seemed to soften his administration‚Äôs stance on visas for Chinese students. The addition to the U.S. delegation of Mr. Lutnick, who was not part of the talks in May, suggested that there could be greater discussion of American export controls, which his agency oversees. The Trump administration also expressed concerns about China‚Äôs currency practices in a report to Congress this week. The talks in London come as many factories in the United States, Europe and Japan are quickly running out of rare earth magnets, for which China produces 90 percent of the world‚Äôs supply. Beijing announced on April 4 that it would require export licenses for all exports of seven rare earth metals and magnets made from them, which are widely used in cars, drones, speakers, fighter jets and ballistic missiles. Kevin Hassett, director of the White House National Economic Council, said in an interview on CBS‚Äôs ‚ÄúFace the Nation‚Äù on Sunday that a goal of the talks would be to get shipments of rare earths from China ‚Äúto flow just as they did before the beginning of April.‚Äù Rare earths are a family of 17 metals found near the bottom of the periodic table. China is particularly dominant in the processing of the seven for which it now requires licenses to export, producing up to 99.9 percent of the world‚Äôs supply. China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce said on Saturday that it had offered to speed up the approval of rare earth exports to Europe. But the ministry also called for the European Union to remove its recent tariffs on imports of electric cars from China, and it called for the bloc to allow more sales of high-tech goods to China. Under pressure from the United States, the Netherlands has limited the sale to China of equipment for manufacturing the most advanced semiconductors.

title: Opinion: A plea to Alaska‚Äôs congressional delegation for responsible economic policy
content: Bottom Line: The Alaska congressional delegation must continue to build the congressional coalitions to accomplish three critical things: ‚Ä¢ Assert congressional tariff-making authority and oversight ...
resumen:
The Trump Administration's imposition of tariffs, tax cuts for the rich, and elimination of cabinet departments and federal employees invite U.S. economic calamity. The trade war tariffs will neither reduce U.S. trade deficits nor bring about a renaissance in American manufacturing. Federal government revenue generated by these tariffs will cover only a fraction of the revenue lost to tax cuts proposed in the federal budget bill. The oppressive, indiscriminate federal workforce reductions brought about by the Department of Government Efficiency raise deep concerns about the delivery of immediate critical health, safety, and welfare services and longer-term agency function. The Trump fiscal plan is corrosive for the U.S. as a whole and disastrous for Alaska in particular.

The Trump administration‚Äôs heavy-handed tariffs on steel, aluminum, automobiles, and other raw materials and finished goods are illegal and will raise the costs of imported cars, equipment, machinery, and supplies to American manufacturing firms and ultimately result in higher costs passed through to intermediate goods and end-product consumers. A tariff on imported goods and services amounts to a sales tax levied on domestic, U.S. businesses and consumers. The blended ‚Äòsales tax‚Äô rate on all imported goods stands at 17.8 percent, up 15 points from its pre-2025 levels. Imports are more than 11 percent of GDP. The chaotic, haphazard implementation of tariff policy is counterproductive to business investment. For Alaska commerce, the impact from this cost structure and supply chain disruption has already fueled business network chaos and American brand destruction. Other damages include 1) weakened crude oil price impacts on state royalty and tax revenue, on Permanent Fund earnings, and on oil company capital project optics; 2) time-critical Alaska seafood market disruption from China and other Asia-Pacific counter-tariff policies; 3) falling tourism bookings and 4) disastrous cost increases on the already budget-stressed Alaska LNG energy lifeline. The ultimate outcome of this trade war for Alaska and American business is higher structural inflation, investment contraction, business slowdown, rising unemployment, climbing interest rates, and widening housing and stock market implosion ‚Äì all tipping the U.S. and especially Alaska toward a recessionary downward spiral.

The proposed ‚Äúbig beautiful‚Äù budget bill passed on May 22 by the House of Representatives will deepen federal debt to $40 trillion or to 125 percent of GDP by 2035. Moody‚Äôs rating agency lowered the U.S. government‚Äôs credit score. The U.S. bond market reacted; yields on medium- and long-term US Treasury bonds spiked. The proposed tax cuts will lower after-tax income to the bottom 40% and raise after-tax income to the richest 10%. Alaska household disposable income and business earnings will be impaired by the combined impacts of regressive income taxation and higher interest costs. The proposed budget bill imposes safety net impairment to America‚Äôs most vulnerable population, including added work requirements and cuts to healthcare spending ($715 billion), SNAP/food stamps ($300 billion), and Medicare ($500 billion). Alaska‚Äôs 279,000 Medicaid recipients (including 109,000 children) would face about $3 billion in uncovered healthcare costs for which no safety net alternative exists.

Over the past 90 days, DOGE has carried out indiscriminate layoffs of about 280,000 federal employees and contractors without consideration for organizational structure and job function. The ripple effect has led to additional job losses, with over 4,400 positions eliminated in related sectors. Alaska‚Äôs 15,000 federal employees, including about 8,000 military, play a disproportionate role in our economy. A 15% reduction in Alaska‚Äôs federal workforce would result in direct, devastating $250 million in lost wages to local business spending, based on $1.6 billion in reported Alaska federal workforce earnings in 2024 from Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development.

The Trump Administration‚Äôs tariffs and tax cuts will cause economic chaos and destruction. Global tariffs have resulted in trillions of dollars in U.S. capital market destruction, enormous financial market instability, and the promise of rising inflation with slowing economic growth.

The Alaska congressional delegation must continue to build the congressional coalitions to accomplish three critical things:
‚Ä¢	Assert congressional tariff-making authority and oversight to reign in the president,
‚Ä¢	Restore congressional authority for federal program formation and spending, and
‚Ä¢	Craft a budget that protects the safety net and keeps guard rails on federal deficit expansion.

title: Transcript: As Trump Tariff Fiasco Worsens, Even Fox News Is Noticing
content: Fox News hosts are pressing top Trump officials to explain his mounting tariff failures. An economist explains what this reveals about the deeper failings driving his agenda‚Äîand what‚Äôs coming next.
resumen:
The economic news has not been great for President Trump. The new Labor Department report found that hiring has slowed, with the economy adding 139,000 jobs in May, and 8,000 manufacturing jobs were lost. Trump still has yet to announce any meaningful trade deals with other countries. Fox News is putting harsher pressure on the administration than expected, with top anchors sharply questioning senior officials about tariffs, trade deals, and the future of manufacturing under Trump.

Economist Kathryn Edwards states that the uncertainty in the economy stems from volatile economic policy coming from the White House, which has very little hope of construction. Companies do not know what is coming, and they can‚Äôt plan or move forward without firm ground. The reasons for concern have shifted from larger economic pressures to a manmade disaster.

The three primary policies that the Trump administration has championed for the economy are to fire as many federal employees and cut as much government spending as possible; to deport as many people as possible; and to start trade wars. Those policies all contract the economy. The Washington Post reported that across federal agencies, there have been desperate attempts to rehire formerly fired federal employees.

The loss of 8,000 manufacturing jobs is a sore spot in this jobs report. Stuart Varney questioned Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer about those lost jobs. Chavez-DeRemer admitted that it‚Äôll take time for the tariffs to reshore manufacturing jobs. Edwards states that manufacturing takes a lot of planning, investment, and certainty about markets. Tariffs, to the extent that they are part of a portfolio of manufacturing resurgence, really come at the end.

Maria Bartiromo questioned Trump trade adviser, Peter Navarro. Navarro says the trade deals are going to take time. Edwards states that trade deals take time. She also notes that the U.S. has midterms, that these tariffs are not popular amongst businesses, and that most members of Congress are under incredible pressure to walk back these tariffs by businesses in their constituency.

Lawsuits are proceeding against the tariffs, and they‚Äôre making some headway. There is also uncertainty flowing out of immigration policies. There are federal cuts that also cause uncertainty. Edwards states that the government is scrambling to put people back into place to fill the functions that were removed.

Edwards expects a slow slowing of the economy. If you can‚Äôt plan, you can‚Äôt aggressively hire, you can‚Äôt make plans for expansions, you don‚Äôt know what interest rates are going to look like, you don‚Äôt know what tax bills are going to look like. If the federal government adds $3 trillion to the national debt, it gets more expensive for everybody to borrow. The path of an economy with major actors under uncertainty will keep looking like this: sluggish reports, not big numbers, trending close to zero, happening slowly. To the extent that these destructive policies are pursued in full force‚Äîlike deportation, or we do have permanently, say, bad tariffs‚Äîit‚Äôs just a matter of how quickly the economy decelerates and leads to recession. We‚Äôre on one path to recession, which is the slow boat. We could jump into the left lane and speed right ahead, depending on the policies pursued. They‚Äôre still basing their economic policy on three destructive policies.

Trump inherited an economy that was in decent shape. The current situation‚Äîall these uncertainties, all the signs that we are on a slow boat to recession‚Äî[is] created by Donald Trump‚Äôs policies. The U.S. economy has everything going for it. We have a massive economy that bounces back from recessions pretty quickly, an unemployment rate that does climb but also falls. We‚Äôre almost always producing jobs. We are sitting on top of a gold mine. We can rest in the fact that we have probably one of the best brain trusts of central banks‚Äîof any central bank in the world.

India eliminated more than 100 terrorists in Pakistan and PoK, including Yusuf Azhar, Abdul Malik Rauf and Mudasir Ahmed. The IAF struck Pakistani air bases, command centres, military infrastructure, and air defence systems. Operation Sindoor caused damage to Pakistan‚Äôs Rahim Yar Khan airbase in Pakistan‚Äôs Punjab province.

PM Modi aims for a Viksit Bharat, turning India into a developed country by 2047. On June 10, just a day after he was sworn in as prime minister, he signed the release of Rs 20,000 crore to 93 million farmers under PM Kisan Nidhi Yojana. The full budget presented on February 1, 2025 gave significant income-tax relief to the middle class by ensuring that people earning up to Rs 12.75 lakh were outside the tax net. The government announced the abolition of 31 per cent angel tax. The government also reduced corporate tax from 40 per cent to 35 per cent for foreign companies besides setting up a Rs 1000-crore venture capital fund for space sector start-ups. India is set to be the fourth largest economy in the world by the end of the current financial year. India‚Äôs GDP grew 7.4 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2024-25, leading to 6.5 per cent growth in FY25. India has signed two major trade deals: the India-European Free Trade Association (EFTA) free trade agreement with Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland and the India-UK Free Trade Agreement (FTA), which is expected to double bilateral trade to over $120 billion by 2030. India is also negotiating a Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) with the US.

In July last year, the Modi government introduced three new criminal laws ‚Äî the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS), and Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA) ‚Äî which replaced the colonial-era Indian Penal Code (IPC), Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), and Indian Evidence Act. The change in laws also introduced as many as 21 new offences. One of the significant ones is penalising sexual intercourse through the employment of ‚Äúdeceitful means‚Äù. The BNS also recognises murder on the ground of race, caste, or community as a separate offence. Moreover, organised crime and terror offences have been defined and covers a broad spectrum of activities.

The Chenab Bridge in Jammu and Kashmir was inaugurated on June 6. The world‚Äôs highest railway arch bridge is part of the 272-km Udhampur-Srinagar-Baramulla Railway Link (USBRL). Modi laid the foundation stone for the Vadhavan Port project in Maharashtra‚Äôs Palghar district last August. Under the Prime Minister‚Äôs Rural Roads Scheme-4 (PMGSY-IV), approval was granted to the construction/upgradation of 62,500 km of roads and bridges to connect 25,000 unconnected villages, with central assistance of Rs 49,000 crore. The government has also approved strengthening India‚Äôs road network with an investment of Rs 50,600 crore. This includes a go-ahead for eight National High-Speed Road Corridor Projects spanning 936 kilometres.

Modi attended the G7 Summit in Italy. In July, PM Modi embarked on a crucial two-day visit to Russia and Austria. During his Russia visit, PM Modi held the 22nd India-Russia annual summit with President Vladimir Putin. PM Modi was conferred the ‚ÄòOrder of St Andrew the Apostle‚Äô award by President Putin. PM Modi visited Ukraine on the invitation by the President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. In February, PM Modi visited France where he was the co-chair at the international summit on artificial intelligence. PM was also among the first foreign leader to visit Donald Trump after he was sworn in as the 47th president of the United States. During his February visit, Trump announced expanded US military sales to India from 2025, including F-35 jets, along with increased oil and gas exports to narrow the trade deficit. Both sides also agreed to negotiate a trade deal and finalise a new defence framework. The US had approved the extradition of Tahawwur Rana.

title: US-China trade talks set for Monday in London
content: LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) - Top U.S. and Chinese officials will sit down in London on Monday for talks aimed at defusing the high-stakes trade dispute between the two superpowers that has widened in ...
resumen:
Top U.S. and Chinese officials will sit down in London on Monday for talks aimed at defusing the high-stakes trade dispute between the two superpowers.

The two sides will try to get back on track with a preliminary agreement struck last month in Geneva.

A UK government spokesperson said on Sunday: "The next round of trade talks between the U.S. and China will be held in the UK on Monday."

Gathering there will be a U.S. delegation led by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, and a Chinese contingent helmed by Vice Premier He Lifeng.

The second-round of meetings comes four days after Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping spoke by phone.

During the more than one-hour-long call, Xi told Trump to back down from trade measures and warned him against threatening steps on Taiwan.

Trump said on social media the talks focused primarily on trade led to "a very positive conclusion," setting the stage for Monday's meeting in London.

Trump said Xi had agreed to resume shipments to the U.S. of rare earths minerals and magnets.

China's decision in April to suspend exports of a wide range of critical minerals and magnets upended the supply chains central to automakers, aerospace manufacturers, semiconductor companies and military contractors around the world.

U.S. officials in recent weeks accused China of slow-walking on its commitments, particularly around rare earths shipments.

White House spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt told the Fox News program "Sunday Morning Futures‚Äù on Sunday: "We want China and the United States to continue moving forward with the agreement that was struck in Geneva."

The inclusion at the London talks of Lutnick, whose agency oversees export controls for the U.S., is one indication of how central the issue has become for both sides.

Lutnick did not attend the Geneva talks, at which the countries struck a 90-day deal to roll back some of the triple-digit tariffs they had placed on each other since Trump's inauguration.

The S&P 500 Index .SPX, which at its lowest point in early April was down nearly 18% after Trump unveiled his sweeping "Liberation Day" tariffs on goods from across the globe, is now only about 2% below its record high from mid-February.

title: Opinion: Tariffs make the world poorer and more perilous
content: President Trump‚Äôs on-again-off-again tariffs have disrupted the global trading system and caused whiplash for businesses and consumers. He has vacillated mightily, announcing tariffs on imports from ...
resumen:
President Trump‚Äôs tariffs have disrupted the global trading system and caused whiplash for businesses and consumers. Raising tariffs undermines trade and weakens economic links that stabilize international relations. Mr. Trump has undercut the entire international rules-based order, including ignoring the rules of the World Trade Organization, hindering its work and threatening to abandon it.

Denying low-income countries the opportunity to develop their economies through trade could lead to a surge of migrants. A retreat from free trade will hurt consumers worldwide through higher prices and more limited choices.

The Trump tariffs will make the world a poorer and more perilous place.

International commerce is already shifting in ways that can deepen geopolitical fissures.

Trade has come to be seen as a zero-sum game.

Middle-power countries such as India now recognize that even U.S. friendship may not protect them from tariffs. Even longstanding U.S. allies such as Britain and the European Union were not spared from tariffs.

Falling trade barriers and declining transportation costs had led corporations to build lean supply chains threaded through multiple countries. This approach drove down prices for consumers, increased product choices, helped spread new technologies and promoted innovation.

Businesses worldwide were already dealing with disruptions caused by climate change and geopolitical flare-ups, including the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Now they have to face the possibility of a trade war resulting from retaliatory tariffs and from many countries‚Äô concerns about becoming dumping grounds for Chinese exports.

Businesses are being forced to focus on resilience of their supply chains rather than efficiency. Companies are resorting to reshoring and ‚Äúfriend-shoring‚Äù.

The viability of rerouting output and restructuring supply chains from China through Vietnam and India has fallen prey to proposed tariffs. Canada and Mexico have not escaped either.

China took advantage of World Trade Organization rules to gain access to other countries‚Äô markets for its exports while limiting access to its own markets. China has also used extensive subsidies and other measures, including forced technology transfers from foreign companies.

Smashing the rules-based global trade system will only create anarchy.

For customers around the world, the retreat from unfettered trade will mean higher prices. For many low-income countries trying to follow the path of manufacturing-led development, the traditional route to building a robust middle class is disappearing. A world with less trade and more uncertainty will be a less prosperous one. All countries, including the United States, will feel the pain.

Eswar Prasad is a professor of trade policy in the Dyson School at Cornell University and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

title: President Trump flexes emergency powers in his second term
content: Whether it‚Äôs leveling punishing tariffs, deploying troops to the border or sidelining environmental regulations, President Trump has relied on rules and laws intended only for use in extraordinary ...
resumen: President Donald Trump is using emergency powers in his second term. He is harnessing emergency powers more than his predecessors, relying on rules and laws intended for extraordinary circumstances. An analysis by The Associated Press shows that 30 of Trump‚Äôs 150 executive orders have cited some kind of emergency power or authority. Trump is using emergency powers to supplant Congress‚Äô authority and advance his agenda. Ilya Somin is representing five U.S. businesses who sued the administration, claiming they were harmed by Trump‚Äôs so-called ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariffs. The businesses convinced a federal trade court that Trump overstepped his authority by claiming an economic emergency to impose the tariffs. An appeals court has paused that ruling. Elizabeth Goitein, senior director of the Brennan Center‚Äôs Liberty and National Security Program, said that there is growing concern that Trump is pressing the limits when the U.S. is not facing the kinds of threats such actions are meant to address. Rep. Don Bacon, R-Neb., believes the courts would ultimately rule against Trump in his efforts to single-handedly shape trade policy. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Trump is justified in aggressively using his authority. Trump has most frequently cited the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEEPA, to justify slapping tariffs on imports. The law, enacted in 1977, was intended to limit some of the expansive authority that had been granted to the presidency decades earlier. The AP found that Trump has invoked the law 21 times in presidential orders and memoranda. President George W. Bush invoked the law 14 times in his first term. Barack Obama invoked the act 21 times during his first term. The Trump administration has also deployed the Alien Enemies Act to justify deporting Venezuelan migrants to other countries. There are 150 legal powers that can only be accessed after declaring an emergency. John Yoo, who as a Justice Department official under George W. content: The feud between President Trump and Elon Musk exploded in public view Thursday, as Musk railed against the president's "big, beautiful bill." ...
resumen:
*   **Trump-Musk Feud:**
    *   President Trump and Elon Musk publicly wished each other well Friday evening, after trading insults and threats.

    *   Despite the public feud between Mr. Trump and Musk, there has been no effort to oust the over 100 administration officials who came from Musk's orbit.

title: Editorial: Horizonte en Corea del Sur se perfila m√°s despejado
content: En su discurso de toma de posesi√≥n, el nuevo presidente de Corea del Sur pronunci√≥ una frase que deber√≠a resonar en Costa Rica: 'La unidad es un bar√≥metro de competencia; la divisi√≥n, el resultado de ...
resumen: La elecci√≥n ‚Äìen comicios anticipados‚Äì de un nuevo presidente pone fin a seis meses de incertidumbre y par√°lisis pol√≠tica en Corea del Sur. En su discurso de toma de posesi√≥n, Lee Jae-myung pronunci√≥ una frase que deber√≠a resonar en Costa Rica: ‚ÄòLa unidad es un bar√≥metro de competencia; la divisi√≥n, el resultado de la incompetencia‚Äô. La incertidumbre y virtual par√°lisis pol√≠tica que aquejaban a Corea del Sur desde diciembre concluyeron el pasado martes. En elecciones anticipadas celebradas ese d√≠a, Lee Jae-myung, del centroizquierdista Partido Democr√°tico (PD), obtuvo 49% de los votos y se impuso sobre su principal rival, el conservador Kim Moon-soo, del Partido del Poder Popular (PPP), que recibi√≥ el 41%. El mi√©rcoles tom√≥ posesi√≥n. Gracias a la mayor√≠a del PD en la Asamblea Nacional, Lee tendr√° un amplio margen de maniobra para hacer frente a los enormes retos que enfrenta el pa√≠s. Esta vuelta a la normalidad pol√≠tico-institucional es una buena noticia, que trasciende el √°mbito nacional e incluso regional. Costa Rica comparte con Corea estrechas afinidades en principios y acci√≥n diplom√°tica; adem√°s, recibimos cooperaci√≥n y, desde noviembre de 2019, ratificamos el tratado de libre comercio negociado con Centroam√©rica. La crisis pol√≠tica en Corea se desat√≥ el 3 de diciembre del a√±o pasado, cuando su entonces presidente, Yoon Suk-yeol, del PPP, decret√≥ la ley marcial, con falsas acusaciones de ‚Äútraici√≥n‚Äù contra el PD. Su intentona apenas dur√≥ seis horas. La poblaci√≥n se lanz√≥ a las calles de la capital, Se√∫l, estableci√≥ un cord√≥n de protecci√≥n alrededor de su Asamblea Nacional y facilit√≥ que sus diputados se reunieran y anularan el decreto. Sigui√≥ un juicio pol√≠tico y la suspensi√≥n del mandatario, quien, finalmente, fue destituido por la Corte Suprema el 4 de abril. El hecho de que, a pesar de esos antecedentes, el candidato de su partido haya recibido cuatro de cada diez votos, es una se√±al de las profundas divisiones en la sociedad coreana. En su discurso de toma de posesi√≥n, dej√≥ muy clara su voluntad de hacerlo, con una frase que deber√≠a resonar en nuestro pa√≠s: ‚ÄúLa unidad es un bar√≥metro de competencia; la divisi√≥n, el resultado de la incompetencia‚Äù. El nuevo mandatario, adem√°s, est√° ante la urgencia de dar mayor dinamismo a una econom√≠a afectada por la competencia global en sectores clave, como semiconductores, y la convulsi√≥n del comercio internacional generada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump. A ello se suma el desaf√≠o social de atemperar las notables brechas generacionales y de g√©nero. Los aranceles unilaterales de Trump, junto a su exigencia de que Corea incremente sus contribuciones financieras por la presencia militar de Estados Unidos en su territorio, est√°n en la primera l√≠nea de preocupaciones y consideraciones. Su enorme complejidad se acent√∫a por la necesidad de mantener, simult√°neamente, buenas relaciones con China, principal rival geoecon√≥mico estadounidense, a pesar de las presiones de Washington para que reduzca sus nexos comerciales con el gigante vecino. Tambi√©n ser√° vital la orientaci√≥n de las relaciones con Jap√≥n. El expresidente Yoon, estimulado por Estados Unidos, facilit√≥ un proceso de acercamiento, que ha llevado a gran coordinaci√≥n en temas de seguridad entre los tres pa√≠ses. El PPD, y Lee como candidato, han sido m√°s renuentes a ella, pero ya como presidente prometi√≥ mantener, e incluso fortalecer, esa alianza, vital para la estabilidad de la zona. A lo anterior se a√±ade un tema a la vez interno y externo: el riesgo permanente que plantea la dictadura oscurantista y din√°stica de Corea del Norte, con un arsenal nuclear creciente, una modernizaci√≥n militar con apoyo de Rusia y una permanente actitud hostil hacia su pr√≥spero vecino. Lee abord√≥ todos esos temas con gran sensatez en su primer mensaje como presidente, al ser investido en la Asamblea Nacional. La ruta que traz√≥ propone una mezcla de profundo apego a la democracia, moderado cambio y apuesta a la estabilidad, el desarrollo y la seguridad. Lee Jae-myung, del centroizquierdista Partido Democr√°tico, es el nuevo presidente de Corea del Sur.

title: Australian military chief calls for war readiness
content: Admiral Johnston declared that Australians had to ‚Äúreconsider‚Äù the country as a ‚Äúhomeland‚Äù from which to conduct combat operations for the first time since World War II.
resumen: Admiral David Johnston, the chief of the Australian Defence Force, issued a demand for higher military spending and the faster development of a war economy. He was responding to US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth pressing the government to raise military spending to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product (GDP). Johnston declared that Australians had to ‚Äúreconsider‚Äù the country as a ‚Äúhomeland‚Äù from which to conduct combat operations for the first time since World War II. Hegseth laid down the law to governments throughout the region at last weekend‚Äôs Shangri-la Dialogue, demanding they escalate their military build-up for ‚Äúimminent‚Äù conflict with China. Hegseth announced he had ‚Äúconveyed‚Äù to the Australian Labor government that it should increase its military spending from around 2 percent to 3.5 percent of GDP ‚Äúas soon as possible.‚Äù Johnston spoke at a conference hosted by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI). Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has not committed his government to meeting Hegseth‚Äôs demand, yet he has emphasized Labor‚Äôs readiness to further raise the military budget. Johnston told the ASPI conference that, in preparing the government‚Äôs 2026 National Defence Strategy: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my job and that of the department to give government that frank advice and a view of what we need to be doing.‚Äù The 2024 National Defence Strategy declared that Australia faced the ‚Äúmost challenging strategic environment‚Äù since World War II and the end of a 10-year strategic warning time for conflict, naming China as the central target. It called for a ‚Äúwhole-of-government and whole-of-nation approach.‚Äù The 2024 document was based on Labor‚Äôs 2023 Defence Strategic Review. Johnston outlined a total reorganisation of the continent. He listed challenges facing the ‚Äúnorthern infrastructure‚Äù including limited fuel storage, long supply lines, a lack of adequate medical facilities, and an absence of industry capable of rapidly repairing equipment damaged in battle. The ABC‚Äôs David Speers commented: ‚ÄúIt all sounded rather similar to the ‚Äòwar-fighting readiness‚Äô Sir Keir Starmer spoke of in the UK.‚Äù At the Shangri-La Dialogue, Hegseth also pushed for ‚Äúan integrated defense industrial base‚Äù to support a US-led war against China. Labor‚Äôs 2024 National Defence Strategy committed the Albanese government to continuing to militarise the north of the Australian continent. This includes greater access to ports and air and army bases, the $368 billion acquisition of AUKUS nuclear-powered submarines, more frequent visits by US nuclear submarines, fuel storage capabilities for long-range US bombers, the rotational presence of 2,500 US marines near Darwin and expansions to the Pine Gap satellite surveillance station in central Australia.

title: Corporate Media Thought They Had Trump On Ropes Over Egg Prices ‚Äî It Quickly Blew Up In Their Faces
content: The corporate media believed they had President Donald Trump trapped in a corner when it came to rising egg prices, ...
resumen: The corporate media believed they had President Donald Trump trapped in a corner when it came to rising egg prices, but the costs of eggs soon dropped dramatically. Despite the media‚Äôs groaning, the price of eggs dropped over 61% since Trump took office on January 20, which went down significantly from an all-time high cost of $8 a dozen in the first week of March. The average cost of eggs amounted to $6.41 on Jan. 21, Trump‚Äôs first full day of his second term, and that number currently stands at $2.57 as of Friday, according to Trade Economics. In an attempt to shift criticism from former President Joe Biden to Trump regarding egg prices, corporate media outlets highlighted expensive egg prices, tried to fact-check Trump‚Äôs statements on prices and repeatedly predicted that Trump would never be able to bring down the costs. The Associated Press wrote on March 7 that the Democrats believed that rising egg prices were their ‚Äúroad to recovery.‚Äù It noted that the Department of Agriculture expected egg prices to go up by 41% in 2025, and quoted Democrats pinning the rising prices on Trump. PBS News also published an April 10 article titled, ‚ÄúEgg prices increase to record high despite Trump promises and curbing bird flu outbreak,‚Äù which attempted to claim that Trump did not uphold his promises to lower egg prices. In February, The New York Times published the headline, ‚ÄúInflation Is Trump‚Äôs Problem Now,‚Äù which claimed that Trump inherited a ‚Äústrong economy‚Äù and would have to ‚Äúcontend‚Äù with rising egg prices due to bird flu. It quoted Jeffrey Roach, chief economist at LPL Financial, stating that the rise in egg prices was the ‚Äúlargest increase in roughly a decade.‚Äù Several outlets attempted to ‚Äúfact-check‚Äù Trump as he touted the prices of eggs coming down. The Times continued to try and highlight the egg prices under Trump even when they dropped by more than half of a percent within just a few months of his second term. Linda Qiu, a reporter for the Times, wrote that the wholesale price of eggs were not yet ‚Äúreflected‚Äù in the retail price, making consumers still pay high prices for eggs. CBS News and CNN both accused Trump in April of lying about the rapid decrease in prices. CNN claimed on April 23 that Trump lied when he touted that the wholesale cost of eggs had gone down by 94% since he began his second term. In a separate article, CNN claimed on Feb. 27 that while Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins provided a detailed plan to lower egg prices, the outlet argued that American consumers should not ‚Äúexpect relief‚Äù on egg prices. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins laid out her ‚Äúcomprehensive strategy‚Äù to lower egg prices in a Feb. 26 op-ed in The Wall Street Journal. Her five-step plan included dedicating $500 million to help poultry farmers with biosecurity measures, provide millions more in financial relief for farmers impacted by the avian flu, research vaccinations and therapeutics for egg-laying chickens, remove unnecessary regulations on egg producers and temporarily import eggs from other countries. As egg prices began to drop, NBC News claimed that grocery shoppers were bracing to pay more for eggs and other food items. A Reuters article from April 3 suggested that Trump‚Äôs tariffs would cause egg prices to soar just as they started decreasing from record-high levels. USA Today columnist Rex Huppke published an op-ed on April 19 claiming that Trump ‚Äúruined Easter with his astronomical egg prices.‚Äù The op-ed claimed that the president ‚Äúfailed‚Äù to lower egg prices, had lied about egg prices going down and made prices soar even more from his tariffs. ‚ÄúThe View‚Äù co-host Whoopi Goldberg falsely claimed during an April 9 segment that egg prices had not fallen by ‚Äúone cent‚Äù since Trump took office, though in reality, the costs of eggs had fallen 44% at the time since the start of 2025. title: Trump Labor Secretary gets caught in a lie by startled Fox Business host, whose eyes bulge
content: Lori Chavez-DeRemer attends a hearing of the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee on her nomination for Secretary of Labor, Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025, on Capitol Hill in Washington. ...
resumen: Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer dodged questions on Friday about the loss of thousands of manufacturing jobs last month. A new jobs report from the Department of Labor found that employers slowed hiring last month, adding 139,000 jobs to the economy. Fox Business host Stuart Varney noted on Friday that the economy also lost 8,000 manufacturing jobs in May after President Donald Trump‚Äôs announcement on tariffs. When asked why the U.S. was losing manufacturing jobs, Chavez-DeRemer told Varney that the U.S. was ‚Äúholding steady.‚Äù Chavez-DeRemer said that under the Trump administration, manufacturing jobs are still up over what the last administration, under Biden had. Varney repeated his question to Chavez-DeRemer on Friday after she did not answer why the U.S. lost so many manufacturing jobs. Trump has repeatedly claimed that his costly tariffs will bring more manufacturing jobs back to the U.S. Chavez-DeRemer doubled down on her response, prompting Varney to raise his eyebrows at her answer. Chavez-DeRemer said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre certainly holding steady,‚Äù as Varney looked startled. VARNEY: 8,000 manufacturing jobs were lost in May. That's not what you wanted to see. CHAVEZ-DeREMER: Well, we're certainly holding steady. VARNEY: But how could we're losing those jobs? CHAVEZ-DeREMER: Well, we're certainly holding steady. Chavez-DeRemer‚Äôs claim that more manufacturing jobs have been created under Trump than former President Joe Biden is misleading, as CBS News reported last year that about 614,000 manufacturing jobs were added during the Biden administration. According to the latest job report, 8,000 manufacturing jobs were lost in May under the Trump administration. Overall, about 88,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost in the last 12 months, according to the data. Trump celebrated the jobs report in a post early on Friday morning. Hiring fell from a revised 147,000 in April, the Department of Labor said Friday. The job gains last month were above the 130,000 that economists had forecast. The federal government shed 22,000 jobs, however, the most since November 2020, as Trump‚Äôs job cuts and hiring freeze had an impact. Factories lost 8,000 jobs last month. title: China‚Äôs rare earth weapon changes contours of trade war battlefield
content: China has signaled for more than 15 years that it was looking to weaponise areas of the global supply chain, a strategy modeled on longstanding American export controls Beijing views as aimed at ...
resumen: China has signaled for more than 15 years that it was looking to weaponise areas of the global supply chain. The scramble in recent weeks to secure export licenses for rare earths, capped by Thursday‚Äôs telephone call between U.S. and Chinese leaders Donald Trump and Xi Jinping, shows China has devised a better, more precisely targeted weapon for trade war. China‚Äôs export license system gives it unprecedented insight into supplier chokepoints in areas ranging from motors for electric vehicles to flight-control systems for guided missiles. Zhu Junwei, a scholar at the Grandview Institution, a Beijing-based think tank focused on international relations, said China has been trying to build its own export control systems since then, to be used as a last resort. Trump said both leaders had been ‚Äústraightening out some of the points, having to do mostly with rare earth magnets and some other things.‚Äù China holds a near-monopoly on rare earth magnets, a crucial component in EV motors. In April it added some of the most sophisticated types to an export control list in its trade war with the United States, forcing all exporters to apply to Beijing for licenses. That put a once-obscure department of China‚Äôs commerce ministry, with a staff of about 60, in charge of a chokepoint for global manufacturing. Several European auto suppliers shut down production lines this week after running out of supplies. Noah Barkin, senior adviser at Rhodium Group, a China-focused U.S. thinktank, said the rate of approvals is a pretty clear signal that China is sending a message, exerting pressure to prevent trade negotiations with the U.S. leading to additional technology control. China mines about 70 per cent of the world‚Äôs rare earths but has a virtual monopoly on refining and processing. European and U.S. executives have warned that the new system gives Beijing unprecedented glimpses of how companies in a supply chain deploy the rare earths it processes. A person who has lobbied on their behalf with Beijing said hundreds of Japanese suppliers are believed to need China to approve export licenses for rare earth magnets in coming weeks to avert production disruptions. A U.S.-based executive at a company seeking to piece together an alternative supply chain said it‚Äôs not a way to oversee the export of magnets, but a way to gain influence and advantage over America. Fears that China could weaponise its global supply chain strength first emerged after its temporary ban of rare earth exports to Japan in 2010. As early as 1992, former Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping was quoted as saying, ‚ÄúThe Middle East has oil, China has rare earths.‚Äù Beijing‚Äôs landmark 2020 Export Control Law broadened curbs to cover any items affecting national security. China has since built its own sanctions power while pouring the equivalent of billions of dollars into developing workarounds in response to U.S. policies. In 2022, the United States put sweeping curbs on sales of advanced semiconductor chips and tools to China. Beijing punched back a year later by introducing export licenses for gallium and germanium, and some graphite products. Exports to the United States of the two critical minerals, along with germanium, were banned last December. In February China restricted exports of five more metals key to the defense and clean energy industries. Cory Combs, a critical minerals analyst with Trivium, a policy consultancy focused on China, said it‚Äôs virtually impossible to know what percentage of requests for non-military end users get approved because the data is not public and companies don‚Äôt want to publicly confirm either way.
