title: Trump signals diplomatic overture to China amid intensifying trade standoff
content: In a move aimed at defusing one of the most consequential trade confrontations in recent global history, US President Donald Trump has confirmed that Chinese President Xi Jinping extended an official ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump confirmed that Chinese President Xi Jinping extended an official invitation for him to visit Beijing. The invitation followed a 90-minute phone conversation between the two leaders on June 5, described by Trump as ‚Äúvery good‚Äù and focused ‚Äúalmost entirely on trade.‚Äù The call was initiated at Trump‚Äôs request. It marked only the second direct conversation between the two heads of state since Trump‚Äôs return to the presidency and came amid renewed volatility in US-China relations.

On April 2, Trump announced sweeping new tariffs on imports from more than 90 countries, with China receiving the harshest treatment. The Trump administration raised duties on Chinese imports to a staggering 145%. Beijing responded swiftly, imposing its own retaliatory tariffs of up to 125% on US exports. Representatives from both countries met in Geneva on May 12 and agreed to a fragile 90-day truce. This agreement paused the most severe tariff increases and set a baseline 10% duty on mutual imports during the negotiation period.

Both nations accused each other of breaching the Geneva agreement. Beijing condemned the latest US export restrictions on semiconductor technology as ‚Äúharmful extreme measures,‚Äù while Washington criticized China for delaying promised rare earth mineral exports. The Trump administration recently issued a formal warning to US companies about the dangers of incorporating Chinese semiconductors into critical infrastructure, citing cybersecurity risks. Additional restrictions were imposed on the export of advanced chip technologies to Chinese firms. China has expressed frustration over new US limits on student visas for Chinese nationals.

Trump revealed that Xi ‚Äúgraciously invited‚Äù him and First Lady Melania Trump to visit China. Trump emphasized that both leaders were eager to meet and resume high-level dialogue. The visit would mark Trump‚Äôs first return to China since his 2017 state visit. Xi last visited the US in 2023 for a trade summit, though his last formal state reception in Washington was under President Barack Obama in 2015.

Trump announced that trade officials from both nations would soon resume in-person negotiations. The US delegation will include Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer. China‚Äôs delegation is expected to feature senior officials from the Ministry of Commerce and Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

On the eve of the June 5 call, Trump praised Xi on social media but also expressed frustration: ‚ÄúI like President XI of China, always have, and always will,‚Äù he wrote, adding, ‚Äúbut he is VERY TOUGH, AND EXTREMELY HARD TO MAKE A DEAL WITH!!!‚Äù. Critics argue that Trump‚Äôs tariff-heavy approach is destabilizing markets and hurting US exporters. Beijing has accelerated its diversification strategy, strengthening trade ties with the BRICS bloc, Southeast Asia, and Russia.

US complaints about forced technology transfers, intellectual property theft, and state subsidies continue to be major sticking points. China resents what it perceives as American attempts to suppress its rise as a global economic power. The Geneva truce is unlikely to survive without meaningful compromises.

title: Germany‚Äôs Chancellor Cracks the Trump Code, but to What End?
content: Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany spoke rarely but reverently, and found a warm reception in the Oval Office. Now he hopes to turn rapport into policy wins.
resumen:
President Trump was sitting in the Oval Office on Thursday, trying unprompted to dispel the idea that he was overly friendly with Russia.

Mr. Trump told reporters gathered for a news conference: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not friends with anybody.‚Äù

He then half-smiled and gestured to the man sitting beside him: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm friends with you,‚Äù he told Friedrich Merz.

Mr. Merz, the new chancellor of Germany, chuckled.

Mr. Trump and Mr. Merz seemed chummy from the start.

Mr. Merz fits the profile of other counterparts Mr. Trump has praised during White House visits, like Prime Ministers Mark Carney of Canada and Keir Starmer of Britain.

Mr. Merz is a tall man. His English is excellent. He comes from the business world. He gave Mr. Trump a copy of Mr. Trump‚Äôs grandfather‚Äôs German birth certificate.

The president called it ‚Äúfantastic‚Äù and said he would hang it in a place of honor.

Mr. Trump said: ‚ÄúI want to welcome you to the Oval Office. It‚Äôs an Oval Office that‚Äôs in very good shape. We like fixing things up, and having them tippy top, like they have in Germany.‚Äù

Mr. Trump went on to praise Mr. Merz‚Äôs negotiating stances, his English skills, his agreement with Mr. Trump‚Äôs opposition to a natural gas pipeline from Russia to Germany that was supported by one of Mr. Merz‚Äôs predecessors, former Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Mr. Merz has famously feuded with Ms. Merkel, as has Mr. Trump.

Mr. Merz knew that Mr. Trump usually does most of the talking with foreign counterparts. He did not fight the trend. He often sat silent for minutes as the president fielded questions.

He welcomed Mr. Trump‚Äôs praise of Germany and smiled through minor slights, like Mr. Trump musing about whether it was a good idea for Germany to increase its military spending ‚Äî as the president has long pushed the Germans to do.

Mr. Trump said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure that General MacArthur would have said it was positive, you know? He wouldn‚Äôt like it, but I sort of think it‚Äôs good. You understand that?‚Äù

Mr. Merz said he did.

Mr. Trump said: ‚ÄúHe made a statement, never let Germany rearm. I think that‚Äôs a good thing, at least to a certain point. There will be a point when I say, please don‚Äôt arm anymore.‚Äù

Mr. Merz chimed in mostly to appeal to Mr. Trump‚Äôs ego and national pride. He thanked Americans for liberating Europe on D-Day, 81 years ago on Friday. He said Mr. Trump could prove equally consequential by backing Ukraine in its war against Russia.

When Mr. Trump interjected to say D-Day was bad for Germany, Mr. Merz waved him off, telling him that America saved his country from the Nazis, too.

Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent attended the meeting.

On Thursday, Mr. Vance and Mr. Rubio sat largely silent on an Oval Office couch for 45 minutes.

Mr. Trump asked about treatment of the AfD over lunch, German officials said later.

Mr. Merz warned him that the party has a history of criticizing America, and of fondness for Russia and China.

Mr. Merz also tried privately to persuade Mr. Trump that the European Union was not created to rival America, but to bring peace on the continent.

Addressing the president‚Äôs trade complaints, Mr. Merz said Europeans buy a large number of cars made in the United States ‚Äî including Mr. Merz‚Äôs own personal vehicle, a BMW X3 that was built in Spartanburg, S.C.

Mr. Trump did not offer more weapons or other further support for Ukraine. There was no trade breakthrough.

Mr. Merz told reporters afterward: ‚ÄúWe have a level of openness and collegiality in our conversations. Building on this, we will certainly have very good conversations in the future.‚Äù

title: What You Need to Know About the Federal Court Decisions Threatening the Trump Administration‚Äôs Tariff Agenda
content: Last week, two federal courts struck down sweeping tariffs that the Trump Administration had recently imposed under the International ...
resumen:
Last week, two federal courts struck down tariffs imposed by the Trump Administration under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). These decisions cover the ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù reciprocal tariffs announced on April 2 on the vast majority of US trading partners as well as the earlier-imposed tariffs on products of Canada, China and Mexico related to immigration and fentanyl. The decisions do not cover the tariffs that the Trump Administration has imposed under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 (Section 232) or Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 (Section 301). Both decisions are currently stayed (or paused), meaning that importers will need to continue to pay the tariffs on their entries. The government has also appealed both decisions.

IEEPA, 50 U.S.C. ¬ß¬ß 1701 et seq., is a national security statute that presidents have historically used as the legal authority for imposing economic sanctions and other national security measures, but not tariffs. On the day of his inauguration, President Donald Trump declared a national emergency under IEEPA with respect to criminal, terrorist, human trafficking and drug activity at the southern border. On February 1, Trump issued Executive Orders (EOs) 14193, 14194 and 14195 (Fentanyl/Migration Tariff Orders), expanding the national emergency to include the threat to Americans‚Äô safety and security from an influx of illicit synthetic opioids into the United States from Canada, Mexico and China and imposing tariffs on products from these countries. As of March 2025, products imported from China were subject to a 20% tariff and non-United States‚ÄìMexico‚ÄìCanada Agreement originating products of Canada and Mexico were subject to a 25% tariff (except certain energy and potash products of Canada, subject to a 10% tariff) under the IEEPA Fentanyl/Migration Tariff Orders. On April 2, deemed ‚ÄúLiberation Day,‚Äù Trump issued EO 14257 (Reciprocal Tariff Order) declaring a national emergency with respect to the ‚Äúlarge and persistent annual U.S. goods trade deficits‚Äù caused by tariffs and nontariff barriers maintained by US trading partners. The order imposed a 10% baseline tariff on all products from nearly all US trading partners and an additional country-specific reciprocal tariff on all products from 57 of those trading partners that was slated to be applied one week later. Amid turmoil in the financial markets and a flurry of bilateral negotiations with affected countries, Trump suspended the country-specific reciprocal tariff until July 9 for all countries except China, for which the tariff rate escalated to 125%. After meeting with Chinese officials in Switzerland in mid-May, however, the Trump Administration suspended all reciprocal tariffs on China except the 10% baseline for 90 days (until August 12) to allow for further negotiations.

The Fentanyl/Migration Tariff Orders and the Reciprocal Tariff Order are the first and only instances in which a president has invoked IEEPA to impose tariffs. Altogether, there are 10 separate lawsuits challenging one or more of these four tariff orders.

On May 28, a three-judge panel at the Court of International Trade (CIT) issued a decision in consolidated cases brought by several importers and state governments challenging the IEEPA tariffs. The CIT panel unanimously ruled that the president‚Äôs actions to impose tariffs under IEEPA are unlawful, and it granted a nationwide permanent injunction to legally bar the government from collecting the challenged tariffs. The CIT held that the IEEPA worldwide reciprocal tariff action is unlawful because IEEPA does not authorize the president to impose ‚Äúunlimited tariffs.‚Äù The CIT concluded that interpreting IEEPA otherwise would amount to an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority. The CIT also stated that if the president wants to address a trade deficit through tariffs, the president already has the tariff authority specific to balance-of-payment issues provided in Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974 (Section 122)‚Äînot IEEPA. The CIT further held that the IEEPA tariff actions related to fentanyl and immigration are unlawful because IEEPA authorizes actions to ‚Äúdeal with‚Äù the unusual and extraordinary threat identified in the relevant order. The CIT granted a nationwide permanent injunction barring the government from collecting tariffs under the four IEEPA tariff actions with respect to all importers, and it ordered the government to take all the steps necessary to effectuate the injunction. However, immediately after the CIT issued its decision, the government filed a notice of appeal at the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit and motions to stay the enforcement of the injunction at both the CIT and Federal Circuit. On May 29, the Federal Circuit granted an immediate administrative stay of the CIT order while it considers the government‚Äôs motion for a longer-term stay pending appeal. On June 3, the CIT ordered that the government‚Äôs motions to stay the enforcement of the injunction will be held in abeyance pending the Federal Circuit‚Äôs consideration of the government‚Äôs stay motion.

On May 29, the US District Court for the District of Columbia (DDC) issued a decision in a case brought by two small businesses selling children‚Äôs educational products. The DDC found that the IEEPA tariffs are unlawful and granted the plaintiffs‚Äô motion for a preliminary injunction to prevent the government from enforcing the tariffs against the plaintiffs. The DDC held that the IEEPA tariffs are unlawful on different grounds from the CIT. Specifically, the DDC ruled that IEEPA ‚Äúdoes not authorize the President to impose tariffs‚Äù at all, which is a much broader holding than that of the CIT. The DDC also agreed that the tariffs pose an existential threat to the plaintiffs‚Äô businesses and issued a preliminary injunction to protect the named plaintiffs from irreparable injury in the event that the CIT order is stayed or reversed. The government has appealed the DDC decision to the US Court of Appeals for the DC Circuit. On June 3, the DDC stayed its preliminary injunction pending appeal. On June 5, the plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion to expedite the appeal over the next few months.

Because the decisions finding the IEEPA tariffs to be unlawful are currently stayed, all importers are required to continue paying tariffs. If the CIT‚Äôs nationwide injunction is ultimately affirmed, importers may be able to seek refunds of IEEPA tariffs already paid. The CIT‚Äôs judgment does not explicitly direct the government to issue refunds, but CBP may institute a process for obtaining refunds in effectuating the injunction. As an alternative, importers could also consider filing a lawsuit to challenge the validity of the IEEPA Fentanyl/Migration Tariff Orders and/or IEEPA Reciprocal Tariff Order.

The Trump Administration may turn to other legal authorities to advance its tariff agenda. It may expand the use of authorities that it is already using to impose tariffs (such as Section 232 and Section 301) or turn to new authorities (such as Section 122, as suggested by the CIT, or Section 338).

title: Canada Unemployment Rate Edges Up to 7% in May ‚Äî 2nd Update
content: And while population growth has slowed sharply to its slowest level in four years, the expansion in Canada's labor force for the month and lackluster hiring meant the unemployment rate ticked up to ...
resumen:
In May, Canada's labor market added a modest 8,800 jobs, better than the expected loss of 12,500 jobs, but matching the weak pace of the previous month and extending a period of no employment growth since January. The unemployment rate rose to 7.0% last month, the highest since September 2016 outside of the peak pandemic years. Total private-sector employment rebounded, rising by 60,600. Full-time positions saw strong growth. Industries exposed to import tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have been shedding jobs. Employment in May was dragged down by the loss of 32,000 public-administration workers.

Douglas Porter, chief economist at Bank of Montreal, stated that the manufacturing sector is under intense strain and the overall job market continues to soften. The mixed report for May doesn't give a clear signal to the Bank of Canada. The central bank opted to leave its policy interest rate steady this week. Deputy Gov. Sharon Kozicki said that most businesses expect activity to weaken in the near term, which puts jobs at risk.

Manufacturing employment fell for a fourth straight month, with roughly 55,000 jobs lost. There was a 15,500-job drop in transportation and warehousing employment in May. The highest unemployment rates among Canada's largest cities were in southern Ontario in Windsor, Oshawa and Toronto. General Motors said it was eliminating a shift at a southern-Ontario pickup-truck plant. Total hours worked were unchanged in May from a month prior, though they were up 0.9% compared with a year earlier.

Claire Fan, senior economist at Royal Bank of Canada, expects that trade disruptions will remain a headwind and anticipates the unemployment rate will peak only slightly above May's 7.0% reading. Oxford Economics' Michael Davenport said he thinks a recession is already underway that it will soon broaden to other sectors and drive the jobless rate to about 7.5% by year-end.

As of May, there were about 1.6 million Canadians out of work. The jobless rate among returning students aged 15 to 24 was up 3.2 percentage points on a year earlier at 20.1%. Summer job postings as of early May were down 22% on a year earlier. The average duration of unemployment has risen, with people spending an average of 21.8 weeks searching for work in May compared with 18.4 weeks the same month last year.

title: US suspends licenses to ship nuclear plant parts to China amid trade tensions
content: The United States has suspended licenses allowing companies to export nuclear power plant equipment to China. The move, taken by the US Department of Commerce, marks a sharp escalation in the ongoing ...
resumen: The United States has suspended licenses allowing companies to export nuclear power plant equipment to China. The move, taken by the US Department of Commerce, marks a sharp escalation in the ongoing trade and technology war between the two superpowers. The U.S. in recent days suspended licenses for nuclear equipment suppliers to sell to China‚Äôs power plants. The suspensions were issued by the U.S. Department of Commerce and affect export licenses for parts and equipment used with nuclear power plants. Nuclear equipment suppliers are among a wide range of companies whose sales have been restricted over the past two weeks. It is unclear whether a Thursday call between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping would affect the suspensions. The U.S. and China agreed on May 12 to roll back triple digit, tit-for-tat tariffs for 90 days. The U.S. claimed China reneged on terms related to rare earth elements, and China accusing the U.S. of ‚Äúabusing export control measures‚Äù. The U.S. Department of Commerce did not respond to a request for comment on the nuclear equipment restrictions. On May 28, a spokesperson said the department was reviewing exports of strategic significance to China. The Chinese Embassy in Washington did not immediately respond to a request for comment. U.S. nuclear equipment suppliers include Westinghouse and Emerson. The suspensions affect business worth hundreds of millions of dollars. They also coincide with Chinese restrictions on critical metals threatening supply chains for manufacturers worldwide, especially America‚Äôs Big Three automakers. Department of Commerce export licenses typically run for four years and include authorized quantities and values. Many new restrictions on exports to China have been imposed in the last two weeks, and include license requirements for a hydraulic fluids supplier for sales to China. Other license suspensions went to GE Aerospace for jet engines for China‚Äôs COMAC aircraft. The U.S. also now requires licenses to ship ethane to China. Houston-based Enterprise Product Partners said Wednesday that its emergency requests to complete three proposed cargoes of ethane to China, totaling some 2.2 million barrels, had not been granted.

title: Hiring in U.S. Remained Steady in May
content: Employers added 139,000 jobs last month, continuing a steady run of hiring despite policy turmoil. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.2 percent.
resumen:
In May, employers added 139,000 jobs, and the unemployment rate remained at 4.2 percent. The growth stemmed mostly from health care and social assistance, which added 78,000 positions, as well as leisure and hospitality, at 48,000. Manufacturing shed 8,000 jobs. The number of jobs created in March and April was revised down by a combined 95,000. The federal government shed 22,000 jobs in May and is down 59,000 since January. Average hourly earnings rose 0.4 percent from a month earlier, and are up 3.9 percent from last year. The share of people age 25 to 54 who were working or looking for work dropped to 83.4 percent.

President Trump called Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, a ‚Äúdisaster‚Äù and urged him to lower interest rates a percentage point. Mr. Trump wrote, ‚ÄúHe is costing our Country a fortune. Borrowing costs should be MUCH LOWER!!!‚Äù Officials have held interest rates steady since January.

Beth Hammack, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, said she had heard nothing to suggest that the Fed needed to immediately lower borrowing costs.

The stock market opened higher after the robust jobs data.

The federal government shed 22,000 jobs while state and local governments added 21,000, resulting in a decline of 1,000 jobs in the government sector overall. Job growth was otherwise concentrated in two sectors: education and health, and leisure and hospitality. Education and health +87,000 jobs, Leisure and hospitality +48,000, Construction +4,000, Government ‚Äì1,000, Retail ‚Äì6,500, Manufacturing ‚Äì8,000, Business services ‚Äì18,000. Employment at temporary help agencies fell 20,000 jobs in May.

The labor force shrank by 625,000 in May, and the participation rate ‚Äî the share of adults working or looking for work ‚Äî fell by two tenths of a point.

U.S. employers added 139,000 jobs in May, and the unemployment rate held steady at 4.2 percent. Unemployment for recent college graduates ages 22 to 27 rose to 5.8 percent in March.

In January, the civilian federal work force across the country had reached a post-World War II peak of 2.3 million, not including the Postal Service. Federal agencies have lost some 135,000 to firings and voluntary resignation, with another 150,000 in planned reductions.

Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania said the state would give hiring preference to former federal workers. Since March, the state government has received more than 7,300 applications from people who said they had federal experience, and so far, state agencies have hired 120 of them.

title: China's e-commerce sellers say Trump's tariffs have been a 'rollercoaster' ride
content: Marketplace has been following Lei‚Äôs business since 2018, just before President Trump imposed tariffs in his first term. Not only did his business survive the extra levies, but Lei said the percentage ...
resumen:
China‚Äôs e-commerce sellers say Trump's tariffs have been a 'rollercoaster' ride.

Shanghai‚Äôs Vicky Su, 31, sells a mix of products on Amazon including toys, boxer briefs and Japanese futon covers. She has kept overheads low by having her parents help and shipping products duty-free to the U.S. under the de minimis exemption.

The de minimis policy allowed items valued at $800 or less to be imported tax-free.

Trump ended the duty-free loophole for Chinese goods on May 2.

The first time he canceled the de minimis exemption was in early February, and he hiked tariffs on all Chinese exports to 10%.

The U.S. Postal Service suspended parcels from China and Hong Kong the following day.

Another e-commerce seller, lingerie manufacturer Lei Congrui, manufactures sheer dresses and other costumes. He sold direct to customers through de minimis, and as a wholesaler.

Lei said the percentage of his sales to the U.S. went up from 50% in 2018 to 70% at the start of this year.

A day after Marketplace spoke to both sellers in February, the USPS reversed course and started accepting parcels from China again. Trump also reinstated the de minimis exemption temporarily.

In February, Su had about 200 orders a day from the U.S. That changed in May, when Trump officially cancelled the de minimis exemption for China and imposed sky-high tariffs of 145% on most Chinese exports.

The U.S. set a separate and slightly lower tariff of 120% on small parcels coming from China or a flat fee of $100 per package.

When Marketplace checked in with Su in May, she said she had no choice but to raise prices and it has hurt business. Her orders have dropped by 60% to 70%.

Lei‚Äôs wholesale business is fine for now because he‚Äôs stocked up on pre-tariff products in his U.S. warehouse. However, Trump‚Äôs punitive levies killed a lot of orders on his direct-to-consumer sales.

On May 12, the U.S. and China had a truce of sorts. The two countries announced in Geneva a 90-day reduction in tariffs as they hammer out a trade deal.

The U.S. tariff on overall Chinese exports was cut from an extra 145% to 30%, plus any pre-existing duties. While an additional duty on small parcels was cut from 120% to 54%.

China dropped tariffs on all American exports from 125% to 10%. This is on top of the 10% to 15% retaliatory duties on certain American exports such as coal and agricultural products, and non-tariff measures such as export restrictions on minerals essential for high-tech products.

title: US-China trade tensions threaten tech partnerships
content: As both the US and China accuse each other of violating the 90-day trade truce agreed upon in May, tech partnership between the world‚Äôs top two economies is falling apart brick by brick ...
resumen:
Trade tensions between the US and China have escalated again as the world‚Äôs two largest economies accuse each other of breaching the 90-day trade truce agreed upon in May. On Monday (June 2), Beijing accused the US of breaching the agreement after US President Donald Trump said China had ‚Äútotally violated‚Äù it. The Chinese Commerce Ministry said that while China had upheld the deal, the US introduced ‚Äúdiscriminatory and restrictive measures‚Äù that ‚Äúseverely undermine‚Äù the agreement.

One of the many fallouts of this trade tussle is that the tech partnership between the two countries is falling apart. Last month, the Trump administration intensified its crackdown on Huawei, saying that the use of the Chinese technology giant‚Äôs artificial intelligence (AI) chips could trigger criminal penalties under US export control laws. The US Department of Commerce‚Äôs Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) said, ‚ÄúUsing Huawei Ascend chips anywhere in the world violates US export controls.‚Äù The BIS maintains that the chips are ‚Äúlikely to have been designed with certain US software or technology or produced with semiconductor manufacturing equipment that is the direct product of certain US-origin software or technology, or both.‚Äù

Reuters reported last month that Washington has ordered a broad swathe of companies to stop shipping goods to China without a license and revoked licenses already granted to certain suppliers. Several US firms have received letters from the Trump administration over the past few weeks, highlighting the new restrictions. The agency quoted sources as saying the letters were sent to firms shipping electronic design automation (EDA) software for semiconductors.

There are allegations that China might also be doubling down on punitive measures against US firms as trade war leverage. According to media reports, Apple‚Äôs rollout of intelligence services in China is being held up by regulators. Apple is working with Alibaba to launch Apple Intelligence for Chinese users. The software would also be embedded in Alibaba devices. However, China‚Äôs internet authority is sitting over approval requests. Experts are linking the approval delays to trade tensions between the two nations. Apple‚Äôs business interests have been hit hard as these restrictions put local competitors Huawei, Xiaomi, Oppo and Vivo in an advantageous position. The firm‚Äôs business is already shrinking in the world‚Äôs second-largest economy. At the start of 2023, Apple dominated the Chinese smartphone market with a 70 per cent share, while Huawei languished at 13 per cent. However, by the first quarter of this year, Apple‚Äôs share dropped to below 50 per cent while Huawei‚Äôs rose to 35 per cent.

Trump is expected to talk to China‚Äôs Xi Jinping in the coming days, as confirmed by US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, also hoped that the two leaders would have a ‚Äúwonderful conversation‚Äù.

title: Tariffs Make the World Poorer and More Perilous
content: President Trump‚Äôs on-again-off-again tariffs have disrupted the global trading system and caused whiplash for businesses and consumers. He has vacillated mightily, announcing tariffs on imports from ...
resumen:
President Trump‚Äôs on-again-off-again tariffs have disrupted the global trading system and caused whiplash for businesses and consumers. He has vacillated mightily, announcing tariffs on imports from practically every U.S. trading partner and then pausing or rolling some back. Legal challenges have added to the turmoil.

Raising tariffs, or at least the constant looming threat of that happening, undermines trade and weakens economic links that stabilize international relations. By shredding rules that have governed trade and by disregarding free trade agreements, Mr. Trump has undercut the entire international rules-based order. This includes ignoring the rules of the World Trade Organization, hindering its work and threatening to abandon it.

Denying low-income countries with growing young work forces the opportunity to develop their economies through trade could lead to a surge of migrants that will put pressure on the countries that receive them. A retreat from free trade will hurt consumers worldwide through higher prices and more limited choices, raising the prospect of political discontent in their countries.

The Trump tariffs will make the world a poorer and more perilous place.

International commerce is already shifting in ways that can deepen geopolitical fissures. Business interests have long kept relationships between rivals on an even keel. In the past two decades, U.S.-China frictions have been smoothed by the eagerness of American companies to sell their products and services to China‚Äôs rapidly growing middle class and to use Chinese suppliers. American investors keen to gain access to China‚Äôs financial markets played a similar role. When China manipulated its currency during the 2000s to gain a competitive advantage for its exports, the presence of U.S. commercial interests ensured that the United States did not take punitive action. For China, the benefits from opening up to American businesses and investors pushed Beijing, for a while, at least, to align its own economy with U.S. free market principles. It eased restrictions on investments flowing into and out of the country, and even took steps to reduce government intervention in foreign exchange and other financial markets.

Trade itself has come to be seen as a zero-sum game, in which one country gains only at the expense of another. That is harmful to resolving differences. If U.S.-China tensions in the South China Sea or over Taiwan were to escalate, a give-and-take on trade matters would no longer be an element of negotiations.

Middle-power countries such as India now recognize that even U.S. friendship may not protect them from tariffs, making them less willing to ally themselves fully with the United States. Even longstanding U.S. allies such as Britain and the European Union were not spared from tariffs.

Falling trade barriers and other factors such as declining transportation costs had led corporations to build lean supply chains threaded through multiple countries. This approach, which emphasized efficiency and lower costs, drove down prices for consumers, increased product choices, helped spread new technologies and promoted innovation.

The Trump tariffs have permanently altered the global trade landscape. Businesses worldwide were already dealing with disruptions caused by climate change and geopolitical flare-ups, including the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Now they have to face the possibility of a trade war resulting from retaliatory tariffs and from many countries‚Äô concerns about becoming dumping grounds for Chinese exports. Even if countries retreat from using tariffs, there is little to prevent them from using government subsidies and import and export quotas to favor domestic manufacturers and restrict trade.

Businesses are thus being forced to focus on resilience of their supply chains rather than efficiency. Companies are resorting to reshoring (bringing production back home) and ‚Äúfriend-shoring‚Äù (running supply chains only through countries that a producer‚Äôs home country sees as allies). This means that producers can no longer take advantage of low labor costs overseas or the efficiency gained by using factories close to sources of raw materials.

Even the seemingly safer approach of friend-shoring has been shattered by Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs, which have been applied to friend and foe alike. The viability of rerouting output and restructuring supply chains from China through Vietnam and India, with whom the United States had more constructive trading relationships, has fallen prey to proposed tariffs. Canada and Mexico, which are crucial to U.S. auto manufacturers‚Äô supply chains, have not escaped either.

China took advantage of World Trade Organization rules to gain access to other countries‚Äô markets for its exports while limiting access to its own markets. China has also used extensive subsidies and other measures, including forced technology transfers from foreign companies eager to invest in the country, to improve the global competitiveness of its companies.

Smashing the rules-based global trade system, which the United States itself had a huge role in establishing, will only create anarchy. With U.S. tariffs on one side and fears of the Chinese export machine on the other, and with few rules that can help ensure fair treatment by their trading partners, countries will increasingly try to go it alone or with a small group of their neighbors, splintering trade even further.

For customers around the world, the retreat from unfettered trade will mean higher prices. For many low-income countries trying to follow the path of manufacturing-led development, the traditional route to building a robust middle class is disappearing. A world with less trade and more uncertainty will be a less prosperous one. That, at least, is one aspect in which Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs are fair: All countries, including the United States, will feel the pain.

Eswar Prasad is a professor of trade policy in the Dyson School at Cornell University and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

The article, "The Greatest Showdown in Geoeconomics is Looming," by Christopher A. McNally, discusses the escalating tensions in U.S.-China relations in May 2025. The Trump administration implemented punitive actions against Beijing, including revoking visas for Chinese students, restricting the export of critical technologies and chemicals to Chinese companies, and curbing global uptake of Huawei Technologies‚Äô Ascend AI chips. These measures were prompted by the belief that China had failed to uphold commitments made in Geneva. U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer cited China's failure to green-light exports of magnets needed for cutting-edge electronics.

China's restrictions on the export of rare earth elements, announced on April 4, 2025, are seen as a geopolitical weapon. The licensing system for seven medium and heavy rare earths (samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, and yttrium) could impact industries from semiconductors to electric vehicles.

Licenses have been issued for magnet exports to Southeast Asia and Europe, but not to the United States. A May 9, 2025 letter to the Trump administration, signed by major car makers and their suppliers in America (GM, Toyota, VW, and Hyundai), stated that the automotive supply chain would be disrupted without access to rare earth magnets. Indian auto producers have predicted production halts in June. European semiconductor firms have also expressed the urgent need to accelerate exports.

The article suggests that the U.S. is unlikely to change Beijing‚Äôs calculus. The author believes that Beijing can afford to wait, as the rare earth licensing system exposes supply chain vulnerabilities. Liu Pengyu, a spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington, urged the U.S. to correct its actions and cease discriminatory restrictions.

title: Canada prepares reprisals over U.S. metals tariffs, EU reports progress in talks
content: The increase in U.S. metals tariffs applies to all trading partners except Britain, the only country so far to strike a preliminary trade agreement with America during a 90-day pause on a wider array ...
resumen:
Canada prepared possible reprisals while the European Union reported progress in trade talks on Wednesday as new U.S. metals tariffs triggered more disruption in the global economy and added urgency to negotiations with Washington.

President Donald Trump's doubling of tariffs on steel and aluminum imports kicked in on Wednesday, the same day his administration sought "best offers" from trading partners to avoid other punishing import levies from taking effect in July.

The move will hit the closest U.S. trading partners - Canada and Mexico - especially hard. Canada is the top exporter of both steel and aluminum to the United States.

Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada is prepared to strike back against the United States if talks with Washington to remove Trump's tariffs did not succeed.

Canada's labour union Unifor called for retaliatory tariffs, while Ontario Premier Doug Ford urged Carney not to "sit back and let President Trump steamroll us."

The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office said on Wednesday that U.S. economic output will fall as a result of Trump's new tariffs on foreign goods that were in place as of May 13.

The U.S. tariff hike on the two metals to 50% from the 25% rate introduced in March took effect at 12:01 a.m. (0401 GMT) Wednesday. It applies to all trading partners except Britain, the only country so far to strike a preliminary trade agreement with the U.S. during a 90-day pause on a wider array of Trump tariffs that ends on July 8.

The 27-nation EU's trade negotiator, Maros Sefcovic, and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said their meeting in Paris was constructive.

title: Bank of Canada must get comfortable with the unknown as long as Trump is in charge
content: The Bank of Canada is waiting for more information from the U.S. on the trade landscape before moving on interest rates. What if it never comes?
resumen: The Bank of Canada is waiting for more information from the U.S. on the trade landscape before moving on interest rates. The Bank of Canada has said it was leaving its key overnight lending rate unchanged as it gains "more information on U.S. trade policy and its impacts." Since Donald Trump reclaimed the presidency, gaining more information about U.S. trade policy has been nearly impossible. Uncertainty is a core part of the administration's plan. Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem said back in April, "We still do not know what tariffs will be imposed, whether they'll be reduced or escalated, or how long all of this will last." Prime Minister Mark Carney met with Trump in Washington. Canada was slapped with a doubling of tariffs on steel and aluminum this week. Fifty per cent tariffs will clobber them. Catherine Cobden, president and CEO of the Canadian Steel Producers Association, said, "At a 50 per cent tariff, we basically consider the U.S. market closed ‚Äî completely closed, door slammed shut, if you will ‚Äî to Canadian steel." U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has called it "strategic uncertainty." Bessent, one of President Donald Trump's key economic advisers, admitted that the United States is using uncertainty as leverage to reshape global trade. The Bank of Canada's most recent Business Outlook Survey, which was released in April and covers the first quarter of 2025, found that "sentiment has deteriorated, and uncertainty is widespread." CIBC chief economist Avery Shenfeld said, "Not that many sectors actually face tariffs, but any manufacturer thinking of building a plant in Canada to serve the U.S. market is going to wonder whether their sector could be next." A recent survey by Bloomberg found that the majority of economists believe Canada will slip into a recession this summer as the trade war deepens and uncertainty bites. CIBC's forecast shows the Canadian economy will avoid an outright recession but suffer through six months of roughly zero growth and an unemployment rate that continues to grind higher by the month. Shenfeld said, "So to some extent, it'll feel a bit like a recession for those at least in the line of fire and losing their jobs." Macklem said at his interest rate announcement on Wednesday that the Canadian economy was "softer but not sharply weaker." Thomas Ryan, North America economist with Capital Economics, said he doesn't expect that will last. Forecasts by the London-based analysis and consultancy firm show GDP and jobs numbers will slow in the coming months. Ryan said the Bank of Canada will start cutting rates at its next meeting on July 30. He wrote in a research note, "Accordingly, we judge that three more rate cuts this year are still on table, which would bring the policy rate down to two per cent." The Bank of Canada says it will hold its benchmark interest rate at 2.75 per cent.

title: Focus: US faces vape shortage as China tariffs, seizures hit Geek Bar
content: Reuters, the news and media division of Thomson Reuters, is the world‚Äôs largest multimedia news provider, reaching billions of people worldwide every day. Reuters provides business, financial, ...
resumen:
Shipments of vapes from China to the U.S. ground to a near halt in May from a year ago, hit by U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs and a crackdown on unauthorised e-cigarettes.

This includes Geek Bar, a brand of flavoured vapes that is not authorised to sell in the U.S. but which had been widely available due to porous import controls.

One retailer said that one of the store's vape suppliers normally receives 100 boxes of Geek Bar vapes per week, but is now getting just ten. Another supplier imposed unprecedented purchase limits.

A U.S. supplier limited purchases to five boxes at a time due to "tariff-related price increases and limited market availability".

Trump's decision to impose steep tariffs on China, now at 30% after peaking at 145% in April, as well as blockbuster seizures of unauthorised vapes, have constrained the supply of Chinese-owned vape brands and Geek Bar in particular, according to five industry sources and notices from U.S. Geek Bar wholesalers.

Between May 1 and May 28 the U.S. Food and Drug Administration recorded just 71 shipments of products labelled as e-cigarettes or vapes from China, compared with nearly 1,200 over the same period last year. Such imports had fallen between 40% and 60% in February, March and April, after Trump came into office, but collapsed in May.

One U.S. regional Geek Bar wholesaler wrote to customers on April 22 that they will be reducing supply volume in the near-term.

Vape distributors expect prices to go up.

Unauthorised vape manufacturers enjoy hefty margins.

Consumers hooked on vapes tend to keep buying, even as the price goes up.

Vapes like Geek Bar - priced around $20 currently - would still be good value even with a $5 increase.

Geek Bar manufacturer, Guangdong Qisitech, did not respond to a request for comment.

Many of the vapes landing on U.S. shelves are manufactured in Shenzhen.

To mitigate tariffs, illicit vape producers can mislabel or undervalue their shipments or spoof their origin entirely to make it look like they came from a lower-tariff country like Indonesia, Vietnam or Mexico.

Vapes from China are often smuggled into the U.S. disguised as other items entirely, such as shoes or toys.

Geek Bar was by far the most popular unauthorised vape brand in the U.S. last year, accounting for around a quarter of sales tracked by market research company Circana in 2024.

U.S. tariffs have driven panic buying of vapes by U.S. buyers, higher shipping costs and increased risks at the border.

Substantial vape seizures were also a big driver of Geek Bar supply issues.

The FDA announced a large seizure in Chicago in February.

New FDA commissioner Marty Makary has pledged to crack down on unauthorised vapes.

Government notices on seized goods show further vape seizures in March and April.

Unauthorised e-cigarettes accounted for some 70% of all U.S. vape sales last year.

Altria CEO Billy Gifford told investors in April that he hoped tariffs would lead to "much more enforcement" of vapes at the border.

Trump's trade war with China has also seen China-U.S. air freight and shipping capacity collapse limiting shipping capacity for cargo including vapes.

The FDA's data only captures shipments properly declared as vapes.

Unauthorised vape makers have also been moving production to Indonesia.

title: The White House Wants 90 Trade Deals in 90 Days. So Far, It May Have 1.
content: In April, administration officials vowed to sign trade deals with as many as 90 countries in 90 days. The ambitious target came after Mr. Trump announced, and then rolled back a portion of, steep ...
resumen: President Trump announced tariffs since taking office in January, arguing it would secure better trade terms with other countries. In April, administration officials vowed to sign trade deals with as many as 90 countries in 90 days. The 90-day goal is a tenth of the time it usually takes to reach a trade deal, according to a New York Times analysis of major agreements with the United States currently in effect. It typically takes 917 days, or roughly two and a half years, for a trade deal to go from initial talks to the president‚Äôs desk for signature. Roughly 60 days into the current process, Mr. Trump has so far announced only one deal: a pact with Britain. Negotiations with China have been rocky. China and the United States agreed last month to temporarily slash tariffs on each other‚Äôs imports. The pact with Britain is less of a deal than it is a framework for talking about a deal. During his first term, Mr. Trump secured two major trade agreements, both signed in January 2020: the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement and a deal with China. The China deal was a nonbinding agreement, known as ‚ÄúPhase One,‚Äù that did not require approval from Congress and that could be ended by either party at any time. It took almost one year and nine months to complete. U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement took 896 days from start to sign. China ‚ÄúPhase One‚Äù Agreement took 623 days from start to sign. The Times analysis used the date from the start of negotiations to the date when the president signed to determine the length of deal making for each major agreement dating back to 1985 that‚Äôs currently in effect. The median time it took to get to the president‚Äôs signature was just over 900 days. With roughly one month before the administration‚Äôs self-imposed deadline, Mr. Trump‚Äôs ability to forge deals has been thrust into sudden doubt. Last week, a U.S. trade court ruled he had overstepped his authority in imposing the April tariffs. In a statement on Wednesday, Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said that trade negotiators were working to secure ‚Äúcustom-made trade deals at lightning speed that level the playing field for American industries and workers.‚Äù In April, Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, suggested that the United States would talk to somewhere between 50 and 70 countries. Last month he said the United States was negotiating with 17 ‚Äúvery important trading relationships,‚Äù not including China. The administration told its negotiating partners to submit offers of trade concessions they were willing to make by Wednesday.

title: ‚ÄòUnfair for US to turn protectionist and ask others to open up‚Äô: Indonesian economist on Trump tariffs
content: In an exclusive conversation with Firstpost, renowned Indian economist Dr Hendri Saparini emphasised that with Trump tariffs and military conflicts gripping the world, the importance of global-level ...
resumen:
In an exclusive conversation with Firstpost, Dr. Hendri Saparini, a renowned Indonesian economist and founder of Core Indonesia (Centre of Reform on Economics), discussed the impact of Trump tariffs and global conflicts on international cooperation and regional relationships.

Dr. Saparini stated that the importance of ‚Äúglobal-level cooperation‚Äù has declined, opening space for fostering ‚Äústrong regional and bilateral relationships.‚Äù

She said it is ‚Äúunfair‚Äù for the Trump administration of the US to turn ‚Äúprotectionist‚Äù in its economic policies while pressuring other countries to open their markets for American companies.

Dr. Saparini highlighted the untapped potential of India-Indonesian ties.

She argued that Indonesia has remained open in terms of global trade and pointed out how Washington DC is more protectionist in comparison to Jakarta.

She explained that the Indonesian tariff for US products is lower if you compare it with other Asean countries or Latin America. The US implemented more than 600 protectionist policies when it came to trading with other nations, while Indonesia only has 300 such measures.

Dr. Saparini said that President Prabowo Subianto should be more careful about trade policy, industrial policy, and fiscal policy.

Regarding India-Indonesia economic relations, Dr. Saparini said that the Local Currency Settlement System (LCSS) between India and Indonesia is going to be a good opportunity. Given the strong relationship between India and Indonesia, they will use LCSS more in business and not in tourism. Another benefit is they can strengthen and stabilise the currency for both of them.

She said that Indonesia is not the priority destination for Indian tourists, and they need to work together to improve the development of the tourism sector. She also mentioned the potential of religious tourism.

Dr. Saparini said that Indonesia and India have institutional challenges, including corruption and bureaucracy. She suggested deep and focused discussions between the government and businessmen in both countries.

Regarding the Trump tariffs, Dr. Saparini said that the impact on Indonesia is not as high as the impact on Malaysia, Vietnam, or other countries. The share of export for Vietnam is maybe 80 per cent of the GDP, but in Indonesia, it is only 30 per cent share to the GDP. If they focus more on trade between Indonesia and the United States, it‚Äôs only 2 per cent of the GDP. She agreed that the economic growth will be slowed down. The projected growth this year is only 4.8 per cent to 5 per cent.

Dr. Saparini said that Indonesia has a partnership with the United States and China. She doesn‚Äôt think they need to replace the United States with China. They need a new strategy for both to increase and have a better partnership with both countries.

She said that Indonesia, President Prabowo, tried to open with other sectors. They need a good relationship with the United States in the technology and financial sector. They are focused on trading investments with China.

Dr. Saparini said that President Prabowo has a different strategy in the international relationship, cooperation, and also widening the cooperation, not only in economics, but also in other sectors.

She said that every country will have their strategy, and also its own goal for the relationship.

Regarding the trilateral relationship between India, Indonesia, and Australia, Dr. Saparini said that the importance of global-level cooperation has declined, opening space for fostering strong regional and bilateral relationships. The three nations can cooperate in sectors like human resources, and technology, and then develop new strategies.

Dr. Saparini said that Indonesia will see a decline in economic growth. The characteristic of the Indonesian economy is traditional. Their economy is based on domestic consumption. Consumption among middle-class households has declined to a share of 56 per cent, so the economy is also witnessing a decline. The real problem is unemployment. Twenty per cent of the total population is facing unemployment.

Dr. Saparini said that the partnership and collaboration between nations should be beneficial.

For Asean, she is quite optimistic about the future. Collaboration between Asean countries will be better for the future. Asean has ties with India, and Japan so then they should seek more opportunities to work together.

title: Trump to Trade Partners: Submit Best Offers Today or Risk Tariffs

The trade war is already here. In the 20th and 21st centuries, there have been many moments of conflict over tariffs and dire warnings of imminent trade wars. Understanding that history helps us navigate today‚Äôs treacherous trade waters. The new American trade policy has forsaken the rules and norms of trade politics and jettisoned balance, restraint, and cooperation ‚Äî principles that have made the current trade system work, albeit imperfectly, for 80 years.

Trade is a major issue in international politics and a chronic source of disagreement between countries. Trade connects the domestic and international spheres. Some producers want access to foreign markets while others want protection against foreign competition. Trade can increase choices available to consumers and lower costs. But foreign competition can cost jobs. Trade produces winners and losers. Trade also affects countries‚Äô international influence and authority. Trade can make countries rich, and national wealth is a key basis for international influence. Trade can also prevent economic growth and diversification, thereby marginalizing countries. Trade politics get even more complicated when trade is instrumentalized to achieve non-trade objectives.

Since the end of World War II, tariffs have been lowered item by item, but tariffs have not disappeared. In 2022, 51 percent of world imports were duty free. Many remaining tariffs are (or were) low or they serve a preferential function. Most industrial and highly developed economies developed behind protective tariff barriers. Tariffs are not the only way to protect a domestic economy ‚Äî non-tariff barriers include quotas, internal levies, value added taxes, quality standards, and foreign exchange restrictions. Every country uses non-tariff barriers, including the United States.

Trade wars rattle markets, raise prices, increase unemployment, weaken supply chains, prompt nationalist sentiment, and strain foreign relations. People suffer in a trade war. The victorious countries in the war set up an organization to lower tariffs and increase world trade: the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade organized eight rounds of trade negotiations between 1947 and 1994. In every single one, national negotiators asked for much and grudgingly made concessions in return.

President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade policy is a rejection of the role the United States has played in the creation of the international trade system and in the world generally. The United States has long been divided over freer international trade and many administrations have introduced protectionist measures. The United States received a waiver from the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for agriculture in the 1950s to limit foreign competition. It restricted foreign products that were manufactured more efficiently than domestic producers, such as textiles, televisions, and cars in the 1960s and 1970s. The United States has also engaged in trade battles with its most important trading partners and closest allies. President Ronald Reagan declared that he would ‚Äúnot stand by and watch American businesses fail because of unfair trading practices abroad ‚Ä¶ because other nations do not play by the rules.‚Äù The Biden administration also endorsed protectionism in order to revive American manufacturing.

This trade war is different because Trump‚Äôs tariffs reject the processes, rules, and norms of the international trade system. For 80 years, restraint prevented the slide into economic recession and full-scale trade war, but now the brakes are off on American trade policy. The American tariffs uphold a zero-sum nationalist rationale and the politics behind tariffs are brutal, bullying, and destructive. The credibility and reliability that made the United States a vital pillar of the international trade system is gone.

resumen: The European Central Bank cut interest rates on Thursday to the lowest level in two and a half years. The central bank‚Äôs policymakers lowered the key rate to 2 percent. Christine Lagarde, the president of the bank, has emphasized that officials are trying to steer the economy at a time of ‚Äúexceptional‚Äù uncertainty. The central bank said that uncertainty around trade policy was expected to weigh on the economy, dampening business investment and exports. The bank lowered its inflation forecasts because of lower energy prices and a stronger euro. The euro has gained more than 10 percent against the dollar this year. The bank forecasts inflation will average 2 percent this year, and then fall to 1.6 percent next year. At 2 percent, rates are seen as roughly neutral. Traders are betting on just one more rate cut in September. Some policymakers, including Isabel Schnabel, an executive board member, have said there are still risks of rising inflation. ‚ÄúEspecially in current conditions of exceptional uncertainty,‚Äù the bank said in a statement, future decisions will be made depending on data at the time of each meeting. ‚ÄúThe governing council is not pre-committing to a particular rate path.‚Äù

title: Trump admin live updates: Trump says Xi 'hard to make a deal with' as steel, aluminum import tariffs rise to 50%
content: President Donald Trump signed an executive order raising tariffs on steel and aluminum imports to 50% on Tuesday afternoon.
resumen:
The 50% tariff on steel and aluminum took effect at 12:01 a.m. ET on Wednesday.

President Donald Trump reaffirmed early Wednesday his respect for China's President Xi Jinping, saying, "I like President XI of China, always have, and always will." However, Trump in a post to Truth Social said he finds Xi "very tough, and extremely hard to make a deal with."

Tariffs for Chinese steel and aluminum imports into the U.S. were set at 50% at 12:01 a.m. on Wednesday.

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian was asked Wednesday about Trump's post during the ministry's daily press conference.

House Republican leaders announced a vote will take place next week on the $9.4 billion rescissions package that eliminates already approved funding for foreign aid and public broadcasting.

If approved, it would eliminate funding at the State Department for USAID and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which funds NPR and PBS. A simple majority is required in the House and Senate for passage. Congress has 45 days to get the package across the finish line.

Wednesday is set to be a big day of meetings as Senate Republicans try to chart a path forward on Trump‚Äôs One Big Beautiful Bill Act. Members of the powerful Senate Finance Committee will go to the White House to meet with the president at 4 p.m.

The Finance Committee is responsible for writing the tax policy components of the bill, including the extension of the Trump 2017 tax cuts. The whole committee is expected to attend the meeting, as well as Majority Leader John Thune and GOP Whip John Barrasso, who are both members of the panel. Senate Republicans are separately expected to meet behind closed doors as a conference Wednesday to discuss the parameters of the bill as a group.

President Donald Trump signed an executive order raising tariffs on steel and aluminum imports to 50% on Tuesday afternoon. The 50% tariff on steel and aluminum takes effect at 12:01 a.m. ET on Wednesday.

The order aims to counteract low-priced foreign steel and aluminum, which the administration believes undermine U.S. manufacturers. It also aims to mitigate any potential national security threats posed by imports.

Trump wrote in the order: "I have determined that it is necessary to increase the previously described steel and aluminum tariffs to adjust the imports of steel and aluminum articles and their derivative articles so that such imports will not threaten to impair the national security. In my judgment, the increased tariffs will more effectively counter foreign countries that continue to offload low-priced, excess steel and aluminum in the United States market and thereby undercut the competitiveness of the United States steel and aluminum industries."

title: M√©xico debe ocupar posiciones activas en estrategias productivas: Lomel√≠
content: M√©xico no puede seguir limitado a ocupar posiciones intermedias en estrategias productivas concebidas sin su participaci√≥n activa ...
resumen:
M√©xico no puede seguir limitado a ocupar posiciones intermedias en estrategias productivas concebidas sin su participaci√≥n activa. Requiere una pol√≠tica industrial, comercial, cient√≠fica y tecnol√≥gica que recupere soberan√≠a, diversifique nuestras relaciones econ√≥micas y fortalezca nuestras capacidades nacionales, afirm√≥ el rector de la UNAM, Leonardo Lomel√≠ Vanegas, en el Foro Jes√∫s Silva-Herzog Flores 2025.

En los √∫ltimos meses el mundo ha vivido situaciones que consider√°bamos dif√≠ciles de presentarse y han regresado disputas comerciales que cre√≠amos superadas.

El exsecretario de Hacienda y Cr√©dito P√∫blico, Jos√© √Ångel Gurr√≠a Trevi√±o, consider√≥ que se requiere un cambio de paradigma en el comercio mundial por las decisiones que Donald Trump ha tomado y la incertidumbre que genera con ellas, pero tambi√©n por la tecnolog√≠a, la inteligencia artificial, las telecomunicaciones, internet y la importancia del comercio en servicios.

Am√©rica Latina no puede seguir siendo exportadora de materias primas, sino insertarse en las cadenas de valor con m√°s contenido tecnol√≥gico, m√°s conocimiento, mayor sofisticaci√≥n.

Latinoam√©rica necesita m√°s integraci√≥n. Chile y Uruguay est√°n exportando servicios digitales; Costa Rica fabrica partes de semiconductores; Colombia est√° incursionando en tecnolog√≠as limpias. M√©xico, por su cercan√≠a y su red de tratados, podr√≠a ser un hub regional de integraci√≥n, innovaci√≥n y manufactura verde.

Se requiere que nuestro pa√≠s establezca como prioridades educaci√≥n, salud, energ√≠a, justicia, seguridad y buen gobierno. Las reformas estructurales siguen siendo indispensables. El comercio no sustituye al Estado, lo necesita como socio y hacedor de pol√≠ticas propicias.

Uno de los cambios estructurales m√°s significativos en el comercio es la regionalizaci√≥n de las cadenas de suministro, as√≠ como la digitalizaci√≥n y el comercio electr√≥nico; la automatizaci√≥n portuaria, el uso de veh√≠culos aut√≥nomos, los drones y el dise√±o algor√≠tmico de rutas para revolucionar los tiempos y modalidades del intercambio; mientras que la sostenibilidad y la competitividad tambi√©n se perfilan como motores complementarios del nuevo comercio global.

En el Foro Jes√∫s Silva-Herzog Flores se reflexiona sobre el futuro del comercio internacional y se analiza si contamos con las instituciones pertinentes y, sobre todo, la voluntad colectiva para imaginar y materializar ese nuevo curso de desarrollo que supere los actuales conflictos y permita arribar a un comercio internacional, mucho m√°s justo, estable, libre de estos vaivenes vividos en las √∫ltimas semanas.

Ildefonso Guajardo Villarreal, exsecretario de Econom√≠a, asegur√≥ que para M√©xico y Canad√° es fundamental no poner en riesgo sus compromisos dentro del Tratado entre M√©xico, Estados Unidos y Canad√° (T-MEC), y poder obligar a Estados Unidos a mantener ese tratado.

A Trump le queda claro que el √∫nico incentivo que tiene M√©xico para estar en la mesa bilateral es preservar el mecanismo de comercio integral en Am√©rica del Norte. Tenemos que abocarnos a defender nuestras posiciones, y no dejar pasar violaciones sin denunciarlas.

Estados Unidos (EUA) se present√≥ durante d√©cadas como el ‚Äúpa√≠s indispensable‚Äù, y ahora Europa, M√©xico, Canad√° y otros pa√≠ses deben hacer propuestas para reformar el sistema multilateral de comercio.

M√©xico tiene una ventaja comparativa que debemos aprovechar. Somos el √∫nico pa√≠s emergente grande que puede tener al mismo tiempo una integraci√≥n comercial m√°s o menos profunda en Am√©rica del Norte, pero tambi√©n una relaci√≥n con Asia, Europa y Am√©rica Latina. Ello le da una posici√≥n privilegiada para una propuesta de paradigma nuevo.

Roberta Lajous Vargas, diplom√°tica y escritora, subray√≥ que esta nueva etapa de las relaciones internacionales podr√≠a denominarse del unilateralismo mercantilista, porque el instrumento m√°s visible que usa EUA para la transformaci√≥n del poder son los aranceles.

M√©xico debe dejar claro que queremos la continuaci√≥n del T-MEC, que estamos de acuerdo con el proceso de integraci√≥n de Am√©rica del Norte y que probablemente este se tenga que profundizar en la competencia con China. Pero ser√° dif√≠cil negociar en las circunstancias donde los aranceles se fijan en la medida que disminuye la migraci√≥n o se controla el tr√°fico de fentanilo.

La directora de la Facultad de Econom√≠a, Lorena Rodr√≠guez Le√≥n, dio la bienvenida al Foro y se√±al√≥ la importancia de analizar el comercio mundial hoy en d√≠a en que se observa la complejidad de lo que sucede con las instituciones formales e informales del orden internacional, cuando el sistema financiero internacional ha cambiado profundamente y hay un reordenamiento en el tablero geopol√≠tico con el ascenso de potencias emergentes y la reticencia de potencias establecidas.

M√©xico debe tomar decisiones, acompa√±arlas de pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas y no solo aprovechar las condiciones internacionales, sino tambi√©n participar en modelar nuevas normas. La econom√≠a mexicana ha evolucionado considerablemente, pero tiene tareas pendientes para aumentar el bienestar de la poblaci√≥n y cerrar la brecha de desigualdad.

title: OECD lowers global outlook
content: PARIS: Global economic growth is slowing more than expected only a few months ago as the fallout from the Trump administration‚Äôs trade war takes a bigger toll on the US economy, the OECD said on ...
resumen: The OECD said on Tuesday that global economic growth is slowing more than expected, revising down its outlook. The global economy is on course to slow from 3.3% last year to 2.9% in 2025 and 2026. The OECD trimmed its estimates from March for growth of 3.1% this year and 3.0% next year. The Paris-based organization said the growth outlook would likely be even weaker if protectionism increases. OECD Secretary General Mathias Cormann said that additional increases in trade barriers or prolonged policy uncertainty would further lower growth prospects and likely push inflation higher in countries imposing tariffs. If Washington raised bilateral tariffs by an additional 10 percentage points on all countries as compared with the rates in force as of mid-May, global economic output would be about 0.3% lower after two years, Cormann added. The OECD forecast the US economy would grow only 1.6% this year and 1.5% next year, assuming for the purpose of making calculations that tariffs in place mid-May would remain so through the rest of 2025 and 2026. For 2025, the new forecast marked a sizeable cut as the organization had previously expected the world‚Äôs biggest economy would grow 2.2% this year and 1.6% next year. Trump‚Äôs sweeping tax cut and spending bill was expected to push the US budget deficit to 8% of economic output by 2026. The Federal Reserve was seen keeping rates on hold through this year and then cutting the fed funds rate to 3.25-3.5% by the end of 2026. In China, the fallout from the US tariff hikes would be partly offset by government subsidies for a trade-in programme on consumer goods and increased welfare transfers, the OECD said.

title: Trump‚Äôs 50% tariffs on imported steel, aluminum take effect
content: Late on Tuesday, Trump signed an executive proclamation to implement, starting Wednesday, his announcement last week to increase tariffs on steel and aluminum imports that had been in place since ...
resumen: US President Donald Trump‚Äôs 50% tariffs on most imported steel and aluminum went into effect on Wednesday, the same day as his deadline for trading partners to give their ‚Äúbest offer‚Äù in bids to avoid import tax rates on other goods from taking effect next month. Late on Tuesday, Trump signed an executive proclamation to implement, starting Wednesday, his announcement last week to increase tariffs on steel and aluminum imports that had been in place since March from 25% to 50%. The new tax went into effect at 12:01 a.m. White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett said at a steel industry conference on Tuesday, ‚ÄúWe started at 25 and then after studying the data more, realized that it was a big help, but more help is needed. And so that is why the 50 is starting tomorrow.‚Äù The increase applies to nearly all trading partners, with Britain the only exception, since it is the only country so far that has reached a preliminary trade agreement with the US during a 90-day pause on a wider array of US tariffs. Steel and aluminum imports from the UK will continue to be taxed at 25% until at least July 9. About a quarter of all steel used in the US is imported, and the increased tariffs will hit strong US trading partners Canada and Mexico particularly hard, Census Bureau data shows. The two US neighbors rank number one and three, respectively, in steel shipment volumes to the US. Canada is even more impacted by the aluminum duties as the top exporter to the US by far at roughly twice the rest of the top 10 exporters‚Äô volumes combined. Prime Minister Mark Carney‚Äôs office said Canada was ‚Äúengaged in intensive and live negotiations to have these and other tariffs removed.‚Äù Mexican Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard emphasized that the tariffs were unsustainable and unfair, especially given that Mexico imports more steel from the US than it exports to the country. ‚ÄúIt makes no sense for the United States to levy a tariff on a product in which you have a surplus,‚Äù he said, adding that Mexico would seek an exemption from the increase. The US receives about half of its aluminum from foreign sources. The tariff increase shook the market for steel and aluminum this week, but particularly for aluminum, which has seen price premiums more than double so far this year. With little current capacity to boost domestic production, import volumes are likely to remain steady unless the price increases undercut demand. The White House also wants trading partners to submit their proposals on Wednesday for deals that might help them avoid Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariffs from taking effect next month. Officials have been in active talks with several countries since Trump announced a pause on those tariffs, but the deal with Britain is the only one reached so far. The Trump administration is now eager to reach more deals, with just five weeks until the tariffs take effect. The US Trade Representative has sent letters asking countries to list their best proposals in a number of key areas, including tariff and quota offers for the purchase of US industrial and agricultural products and plans to resolve any non-tariff barriers. Other requested items include any commitments on digital trade and economic security, along with country-specific commitments, according to the letter. Japan, a major US trading partner, has not received the letter, government spokesperson Yoshimasa Hayashi said at a press conference. ‚ÄúRegarding US tariff measures, negotiations are underway between Japan and the United States,‚Äù Hayashi said. ‚ÄúThe government will keep on tackling them, doing our utmost and giving them a top priority.‚Äù

title: Trump Wants America to Make Things Again. Does It Have What It Takes?
content: President Trump wants to revive factories, using tariffs as a tool. Companies that want to re-shore manufacturing are grappling with how to do it.
resumen: The Saitex factory in Dong Nai, Vietnam, makes 500,000 pairs of jeans a month. The Saitex factory in Los Angeles oversees around 250 people who sew, cut and distress jeans for brands like Everlane, J. Crew and Ralph Lauren, and they stitch together 70,000 pairs of jeans a month. Saitex runs a much bigger factory and fabric mill in southern Vietnam where thousands of workers churn out 500,000 pairs of jeans a month. Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs have upended supply chains, walloped businesses and focused the minds of corporate leaders on one question: Does America have what it takes to bring jobs back? The United States lacks nearly every part of the manufacturing ecosystem ‚Äî the workers, the training, the technology and the government support. Vietnam, at 46 percent, was one of the hardest hit by the tariffs. The U.S. Court of International Trade deemed the tariffs illegal. American factories are already short about 500,000 workers, according to Wells Fargo economists. Saitex opened a factory in Los Angeles in 2021. Saitex could probably bring about 20 percent of production to the States, up from 10 percent today. There are no mills in America on the scale of what the industry needs, nor major zipper and button suppliers. A sewing machine operator earns $4,000 a month in Los Angeles, compared with $500 in Vietnam. American factories are already struggling to fill around 500,000 manufacturing jobs, according to estimates by Wells Fargo economists. They calculate that to get manufacturing as a share of employment back to the 1970s peak that Mr. Trump has sometimes called for, new factories would have to open and hire 22 million people. There are currently 7.2 million unemployed people. Saitex ships bales of American cotton to Vietnam, where its two-story mill turns fluffy cotton lint into thread and, eventually, rolls of fabric. Saitex has plowed around $150 million in Vietnam, where its factory recycles 98 percent of its water, air dries its denim and uses technology to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and cut down on labor-intensive practices. In the United States, Saitex has spent around $25 million. If Mr. Trump decided to stick to his original 46 percent tariff on Vietnam and Saitex could not soften the financial blow, it would have to look to other markets to sell the products it made in Vietnam ‚Äî like Europe, where it sends about half of what it currently makes.

UU. de construir muros fronterizos, perseguir y deportar migrantes esposados, imponer aranceles a los productos de ALC, gravar las remesas, etc., pero tambi√©n pesa la creciente incidencia de China en el mundo, en los √°mbitos econ√≥mico, pol√≠tico, cultural y militar. La pol√≠tica industrial de Pek√≠n ha transformado el equilibrio econ√≥mico global, impulsando su ascenso exponencial, disputando la supremac√≠a de EE. UU. La Iniciativa de Seguridad Global (ISG), constituye la propuesta de Pek√≠n para promover la seguridad com√∫n en aras de la paz y la tranquilidad mundiales. La Iniciativa para una Civilizaci√≥n Global (ICG), postula el respeto a la diversidad de las civilizaciones que pueblan el orbe, se adscribe a valores comunes de la humanidad.
