title: A New Era of Trade Warfare Has Begun for the U.S. and China
content: Instead of battling over tariffs, Washington and Beijing have turned to a potentially far more harmful strategy: flexing their control over global supply chains.
resumen:
The U.S.-China trade conflict is evolving into a fight over global supply chains, with both nations limiting the sharing of critical technologies.

The United States suspended some sales to China of components and software used in jet engines and semiconductors. This was a response to Beijing's restrictions on the export of minerals used in manufacturing.

The supply chain warfare has alarmed companies that rely on components from both countries. Officials in Washington are nervous about other areas where China could exert pressure, such as pharmaceuticals or shipping.

Liza Tobin, a former White House national security adviser and now the managing director at Garnaut Global, stated that the "supply chain wars that we‚Äôve been speculating about for years are now happening."

The airplane industry has become both a weapon and a victim in this conflict.

Jet engine technology and navigation systems largely come from the United States, developed by companies like General Electric. China needs engine technology from GE Aerospace to build a competitor to Boeing.

However, jet engines also require minerals processed in China, essential for coatings and components.

Beijing restricted exports of these minerals, known as rare earths, in April after President Trump began imposing high tariffs on Chinese imports.

This move has threatened advanced manufacturing in the United States, including work done by defense contractors. Ford Motor temporarily closed a factory in Chicago due to a shortage of magnets.

The United States responded with its own tech restrictions. U.S. officials suspended some licenses that allowed American companies to ship airplane technology to China, as well as others related to biotechnology and semiconductors.

The Department of Defense, the Department of the Interior, and the National Security Council are accelerating efforts to find more domestic supplies of rare earths, including considering U.S. government funding for new mines and processing facilities.

Developing a single mine in the United States has taken an average of 29 years, according to S&P statistics.

The Trump administration is considering including major Chinese chipmakers, as well as units of Chinese technology giants like Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu, on an entity list that prohibits trade with the United States.

Both countries have been trying to guard against the other‚Äôs control of strategic goods by diversifying their own sources of supply.

After Mr. Trump levied tariffs on China during his first term, many American companies established factories in countries outside of China, including Vietnam and Mexico. Xi Jinping, China‚Äôs leader, set out to make his country less reliant on foreign sources of energy and technology by pumping huge investments into factories making semiconductors, solar panels and electric vehicles.

The economies remain deeply integrated, with hundreds of billions of dollars in trade flowing across the Pacific each year.

Since 2022, the United States has been expanding a global system to regulate advanced semiconductors and stop the technology from flowing to China.

The United States has extended these export controls around the world, even forbidding companies in other countries from selling products to China if they use American parts, technology or software to manufacture them.

China's rare earth minerals are a way to challenge the American assertion of dominance.

Beijing set up a licensing system to monitor and approve sales of rare earths. When Mr. Trump ratcheted up tariffs on China to 145 percent in April, Beijing responded by targeting shipments of rare earths, including pausing many of them.

In May, American and Chinese officials arranged a meeting in Geneva to try to defuse their trade tensions. Negotiators agreed to lower tariffs. As part of the deal, China said it would ‚Äúsuspend or remove the non-tariff countermeasures taken against the United States since April,‚Äù according to a joint statement.

U.S. officials say Chinese shipments have yet to return to their previous levels. Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative, said that the Chinese were ‚Äúslow-rolling their compliance.‚Äù

Mr. Trump wrote that China had ‚ÄúTOTALLY VIOLATED ITS AGREEMENT WITH US.‚Äù

Lin Jian, a spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, denied the accusation, saying that China had ‚Äúearnestly implemented‚Äù the consensus reached in Geneva. Chinese officials say it is the United States that broke the deal, including by issuing a notice saying that the use of chips made by Huawei, the Chinese technology firm, anywhere in the world violated U.S. law.

While some U.S. auto and electronics makers have recently received licenses from China for mineral shipments, the uncertainty and continued backlog of requests for the products are continuing to make companies nervous. China had also appeared to be giving preference to European companies over American ones.

The Trump administration has also proposed plans to ‚Äúaggressively revoke‚Äù visas of Chinese students, including those with ties to the Communist Party.

Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, said Monday that Mr. Trump and Mr. Xi would likely speak in a call this week.

Daniel H. Rosen, the co-founder of Rhodium Group, said that Beijing recognized years ago that rare earths would be central to advanced technologies and subsidized the build-out of those supplies.

China mines 70 percent of the world‚Äôs rare earths, but it does the chemical processing for 90 percent of them. The country also makes more than 80 percent of the world‚Äôs batteries, more than 70 percent of its electric cars, and about half of the world‚Äôs steel, iron and aluminum, according to data from the International Energy Agency.

Securing an alternative supply would likely require the United States to invest hundreds of billions of dollars, Mr. Rosen said, and cooperation with global partners who were willing to work to set up supply chains outside of China.

Paul Triolo, a partner at Albright Stonebridge Group, said the Chinese licensing system was cumbersome and that there had been a notable drop in shipments of critical minerals since the start of April, when Mr. Trump first issued astronomical tariffs on China.

Mr. Triolo said the United States had no choice except to negotiate with Beijing on the issue, as well as set up a long-term strategy with other countries to reduce its dependence on China over the next five to seven years.

title: Higher Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum Imports Go Into Effect
content: The president has ratcheted up the rate on foreign metals to 50 percent, double the previous rate, saying the levies weren‚Äôt high enough to help the U.S. industry.
resumen: U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports doubled on Wednesday. The increased tariffs rose to 50 percent from 25 percent just after midnight Eastern time. They were announced during Mr. Trump‚Äôs visit to a U.S. Steel mill last week. The higher levies have already rankled close allies that sell metal to the United States, including Canada and Europe. In an executive order, Mr. Trump said the higher tariffs would ‚Äúmore effectively counter foreign countries that continue to offload low-priced, excess steel and aluminum in the United States market and thereby undercut the competitiveness of the United States steel and aluminum industries.‚Äù Kevin Dempsey, the president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, praised the move. Robert Budway, the president of the Can Manufacturers Institute, said doubling the steel tariff would further increase the cost of canned goods at the grocery store. Wednesday‚Äôs increase is the latest in a mounting array of import taxes that Mr. Trump has announced since returning to the Oval Office in January, including the 25 percent tariff on steel and aluminum in March. An economic analysis published by the U.S. International Trade Commission suggested that while the steel and aluminum tariffs levied in Mr. Trump‚Äôs first term helped American steel and aluminum producers, they hurt the broader economy by raising prices for many other industries, including automaking. U.S. unions and major companies like Cleveland-Cliffs and U.S. Steel have argued that tariffs are necessary to keep them in business. After struggling financially for years, U.S. Steel agreed in late 2023 to be acquired by Nippon Steel of Japan, though Mr. Trump will make the final call on whether the merger can go through. Canada is the largest foreign supplier of both steel and aluminum to the United States. Mexico, Brazil, South Korea and Germany are also major suppliers of steel, while the United Arab Emirates, China and South Korea supply the United States with small amounts of aluminum. Where the United States imported steel and aluminum from in 2024: Steel $32 bil. Canada 22.5%, Mexico 11.0%, Brazil 9.4%, South Korea 9.1%, Germany 6.0%, Japan 5.5%, Taiwan 4.2%, Vietnam 3.6%, Italy 2.8%, China 2.5%, Neth. 2.4%, Austria 1.8%, U.A.E. 1.0%. Aluminum $18 bil. Canada 53.3%, U.A.E. 5.2%, China 4.6%, South Korea 4.4%, Bahrain 3.0%. Catherine Cobden, the president of the Canadian Steel Producers Association, said doubling the tariff on imported steel ‚Äúessentially closes the U.S. market to our domestic industry.‚Äù The steel association estimates that since the tariff went into effect in March, steel shipments to the United States from Canada have fallen 30 percent. The Aluminium Association of Canada said in a statement on Tuesday that the expanded tariff ‚Äúmakes Canadian exports to the U.S. economically unviable‚Äù and that ‚Äúthe industry may be forced to diversify trade toward the European Union.‚Äù Electricity accounts for about 40 percent of the cost of smelting aluminum. The Canadian industry supports the U.S. goal of increasing domestic aluminum production capacity from 50 percent to 80 percent. Century Aluminum, a U.S. aluminum maker, said last year that it would build the first new aluminum smelter in the United States in half a century, doubling domestic production.

title: US inflation not to ease before 2026 as Trump tariffs slow down America's economy
content: The OECD now projects US growth to slow significantly to 1.6 per cent this year, a substantial revision from its earlier March forecast of 2.2 per cent growth for 2025 ...
resumen:
US inflation pressures may persist until at least 2026, driven by President Donald Trump‚Äôs escalating tariffs that are slowing economic growth, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development said Tuesday (June 3).

The OECD downgraded its economic forecasts for the United States, citing continued trade conflicts, rising policy uncertainty, reduced net immigration, and a shrinking federal workforce.

The organisation now projects US. growth to slow. significantly to 1.6 per cent this year, a substantial revision from its earlier March forecast of 2.2 per cent growth for 2025.

OECD has further predicted US‚Äô economic growth declining to 1.5 per cent in 2026.

Recently, Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller acknowledged that tariffs would likely boost inflation and unemployment in the short term.

Speaking at an economic forum, Waller expressed concerns about the uncertainty surrounding the tariff policies, particularly following President Trump‚Äôs decision on Friday to double steel and aluminum tariffs from 25 per cent to 50 per cent.

Waller said, ‚ÄúAs of today, I see downside risks to economic activity and employment and upside risks to inflation in the second half of 2025,‚Äù according to. Bloomberg. ‚ÄúBut how these risks evolve is strongly tied to how trade policy evolves.‚Äù

Waller added that while tariffs are expected to push inflation higher in coming months, the Federal Reserve remains inclined to ‚Äúlook through‚Äù temporary price increases, provided inflation expectations remain stable.

Goldman Sachs economists stated in a recent report, according to. Axios. ‚ÄúWe are skeptical about the prospects for prolonged high inflation amidst mediocre economic performance.‚Äù

Goldman analysts warned that inflation could persist longer if country-specific tariffs return to prohibitive levels or continue escalating into 2026.

title: Pushback against Trump‚Äôs tariffs
content: Trade policy uncertainty will continue as the US President, with his on and off agenda to impose levies to strike deals favourable to America, will not back down.
resumen: US President Donald Trump is doubling down on his disruptive tariff agenda despite facing a major setback with the US Court of International Trade (CIT) ruling that he overstepped his authority to impose sweeping global tariffs. This landmark judgment has been paused by an appeals court. The judgment does not impinge on his ability to impose sectoral tariffs under Section 232 of the US Trade Expansion Act of 1962 on steel and aluminium or autos and plans to do the same for pharmaceuticals and semiconductors on national security grounds. He has now increased levies on imported steel and aluminium to 50% from 25%. Trump is unfazed by the US judiciary‚Äôs pushback, which also includes a separate ruling by a federal judge in Washington declaring a number of tariffs unlawful. The CIT observed that the federal law did not grant him ‚Äúunbounded authority‚Äù to impose tariffs on nearly every country of the world. Before Trump 2.0, no US president had invoked provisions of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to levy such duties. Tariffs are not part of this 1977 law. The CIT also said that the US Constitution provides the Congress exclusive authority to regulate trade with other nations, which is not overridden by his invocation of national emergency powers. Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974 allows him to impose tariffs of 15% for only 150 days to address the country‚Äôs balance-of-payments deficits. Trump can also take recourse to Section 338 of the Tariff Act of 1930 if US businesses suffer from unfair discrimination. Tariffs are capped at 50%. This overlaps with Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 which allows the United States Trade Representative to impose tariffs on countries that violate existing trade agreements. The Congress can also grant him exclusive powers on tariffs. The higher levies on steel and aluminium ‚Äî which take effect on June 4 ‚Äî will adversely affect India‚Äôs exports of these commodities that amounted to $4.56 billion in FY25. India has already issued a notice at the World Trade Organization of its intentions to impose retaliatory tariffs in response to the earlier steel duties of 25%. The US has rejected this notice stating that its Section 232 tariffs were not safeguard measures but related to national security. Trump is not making it any easier with gratuitous statements that India has ‚Äúoffered a deal where basically they are willing to literally charge us no tariffs‚Äù. Although reports indicate that a deal is likely before June 25 ‚Äî with US officials expected to visit India in this regard. Talks between the US and China in Geneva rolled back some of the highest tariffs of 145%. Trump has now accused the dragon of violating this agreement. Assuming the global tariffs introduced under the IEEPA are invalidated, thanks to the CIT, Trump‚Äôs tariff bluster and foreign retaliation till end-May take average US levies to 7% ‚Äî the highest since 1969 ‚Äî according to Budget Lab at Yale University.

title: Trump Tariffs-Induced Volatility Widens CRE Opportunity for Private Credit
content: A s President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff policy sends continued shockwaves through commercial real estate, private credit may stand to benefit from the volatility.
resumen:
As President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff policy sends continued shockwaves through commercial real estate, private credit may stand to benefit from the volatility.

The U.S. Court of International Trade on May 28 blocked Trump‚Äôs unilateral reciprocal tariffs, but the issue may ultimately be decided by the U.S. Supreme Court.

The trade court decision was one of many twists and turns since Trump‚Äôs April 2 ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariff announcement, with many of the unknowns sidelining banks from financing deals ‚Äî while generating more opportunities for established private lenders.

Josh Zegen, co-founder and managing principal of Madison Realty Capital, said that private credit has smoothed some of the volatility in the market and that private lenders have been able to take a little bigger market share in general because they have broad product array.

Zegen noted that Madison Realty Capital and other nonbank lenders have been originating an increasing number of construction financings that are sub-65 percent loan-to-cost ‚Äî levels previously provided by banks, with banks now facing even more stringent underwriting standards due to regulatory requirements.

Alternative lenders had already begun to gain increased market share in CRE deals in the last three years, with banks sidelined amid higher interest rates and increasing regulatory scrutiny.

Greg Friedman, managing principal and CEO of nonbank lender Peachtree Group, said that private credit is important given that 20 percent ($957 billion) of $4.8 trillion of outstanding CRE loans were scheduled to mature this year, according to data released by the Mortgage Bankers Association in February.

Twenty-five percent of the outstanding commercial mortgages ($452 billion) was derived from balance sheet loans originated by banks.

Friedman is projected to achieve more than $2 billion this year based on its current pipeline, after originating $1.6 billion of lending volume in 2024.

Banks had begun to reduce their CRE balance sheets going back to the end of the Global Financial Crisis of 2008, and further deleveraged when interest rates began to soar three years ago.

Prior to Trump enacting steeper tariffs this year, banks showed renewed signs of life with balance sheet loans capturing 34 percent of loans in the CBRE Lending Momentum Index for the first quarter of 2025, a 90 percent year-over-year growth.

Alternative lenders comprised 19 percent of non-agency CBRE closings, down from 48 percent a year earlier.

The Federal Reserve enacted 11 interest rate hikes out of 12 meetings between March 2022 to July 2023 before a 14-month pause.

The central bank then shifted its inflation-fighting policy in late 2024 with three cuts totaling 100 basis points in its final three meetings of last year.

The Fed has held borrowing conditions firm so far in 2025 amid economic uncertainties posed by the Trump administration policies regarding tariffs and immigration that could worsen inflation.

Trump agreed to a 90-day pause with most countries on April 9, followed by another 90-day pause with China on May 12 that temporarily suspended a 145 percent tariff.

Trump then recommended 50 percent tariffs on the European Union on May 23, causing markets to tumble before. Trump then decided to delay such a move until at least July.

Michael Lavipour, head of lending at Affinius Capital, said that the volatility in the market has slowed acquisition and development deals, but it also creates opportunities for private lenders to step in with refinances or recapitalizations for property owners faced with higher borrowing costs on loans coming due.

In addition to increased lending opportunities for recaps and refis, private credit is also expanding in large part to an increasing number of banks looking to partner with alternative lenders for note-on-note financing, according to Lavipour, whose team has expanded this practice over the past 12 months.

Lavipour said more regional banks are focusing primarily on note-on-note financing as a way to reduce overhead and obtain capital relief.

Friedman said partnering with banks on note-on-note financing or selling outstanding loans has become an increasing element of Peachtree‚Äôs credit business.

Regional banks, which have roughly one-third of their balance sheets exposed to CRE assets compared to around 7 to 8 percent with national banks, are in particular turning to private credit in times of market dislocation.

Manish Shah, senior managing director at Palladius Capital Management, said that in times of market dislocation, where there are concerns about potential cost overruns for construction projects, a more ‚Äúnuanced approach‚Äù by private lenders can be attractive to borrowers seeking capital.

The U.S. Court of International Trade decision added another layer of uncertainty to the CRE market with Trump‚Äôs tariff policies now likely headed for an appeals process while the administration also explores other tools to enact them.

Zegen expects private credit to gain market share in 2025.

title: As Trade Talks Stall, Trump Tightens Pressure on China
content: The Trump administration has recently rolled out a series of new export control measures targeting China. While these moves are officially justified on national security grounds, it‚Äôs clear that they ...
resumen:
China and the United States reached a 90-day truce on tariffs during talks in Geneva on May 12, but trade negotiations are still ongoing.

On May 29, U.S. Treasury Secretary Bessent said trade talks with China had stalled. He suggested a phone call between the two leaders might be necessary to break the deadlock.

President Donald Trump accused China of failing to honor his goodwill and having ‚Äútotally violated its agreement with us.‚Äù Trump indicated he was very frustrated.

The Trump administration has taken steps outside the negotiating table to increase pressure on Beijing, including tightening restrictions on tech exports to China and stepping up scrutiny of Chinese students applying for U.S. visas.

China may consider countermeasures such as restricting rare earth exports or strengthening ties with the European Union.

The United States and China face deep-rooted, structural conflicts over trade issues such as currency manipulation, export subsidies, and other non-tariff barriers.

In May 2019, talks collapsed. The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative accused China of backtracking on previously agreed commitments by removing key pledges from a nearly 150-page draft agreement, including chapters on intellectual property protection, forced technology transfers, and unfair trade practices such as export subsidies.

China‚Äôs leaders believe that Trump is under greater pressure than they are.

The Trump administration has rolled out new export control measures targeting China.

On May 29, the administration announced a halt on the sale of certain critical U.S. technologies to China, including those related to jet engines, semiconductors, and specific chemicals.

The U.S. Department of Commerce suspended licenses that had allowed American companies to sell key products and technologies to China‚Äôs state-owned aircraft manufacturer, COMAC, for the development of its C919 passenger jet.

The Trump administration is moving to block China‚Äôs access to advanced semiconductor design tools. U.S. companies that provide electronic design automation (EDA) software ‚Äì including Synopsys, Cadence, and Siemens EDA ‚Äì have been ordered to stop selling their services to Chinese firms.

Synopsys, Cadence, and Siemens collectively hold more than 70 percent of the EDA market share in China.

The Trump administration has also targeted Chinese students enrolled at American universities. It announced plans to revoke the visas of students with links to the Chinese Communist Party or those studying in ‚Äúcritical fields.‚Äù

There are more than 270,000 Chinese students currently studying in the United States.

China is the second-largest source of international students in the U.S. after India.

On May 14, China announced a 90-day suspension of export restrictions on 28 U.S. entities, covering rare earth elements and other items with potential military applications. China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce declared a parallel 90-day pause on trade and investment bans affecting 17 American companies.

Beijing is likely to reinstate rare earth export restrictions to the U.S. China dominates the global rare earth supply chain, producing 60 percent of the world‚Äôs supply and handling 90 percent of processing. It may also resume trade and investment bans on select American firms.

On May 27, China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce hosted a roundtable with upstream and downstream players in the China-EU semiconductor supply chain, briefing them on the country‚Äôs rare earth export control policies.

China may ease rare earth export restrictions on European companies.

China may also mobilize U.S. businesses with significant commercial interests in the Chinese market to apply indirect pressure on the Trump administration.

American EDA software companies such as Synopsys and Cadence have substantial commercial interests in China.

The U.S. Department of Commerce‚Äôs decision to halt the sale of jet engines to China could also lead to breaches of existing procurement contracts.

title: Tracking Trump and Latin America: Trade‚ÄîHigher Tariffs on Aluminum and Steel in Effect
content: What does the U.S. president's ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù trade policy mean for the region? AS/COA is monitoring the new administration's approach.
resumen:
On June 4, the Trump administration increased the tariffs on aluminum and steel to 50 percent. This doubles the 25 percent rate that had been in effect since May 12. President Trump had announced the upcoming increase during his visit to a steel factory in Pennsylvania on May 30.

The higher tariff goes into effect on June 4. It will impact imports from countries like Argentina, Brazil, Canada, and Mexico. The United Kingdom is exempted from the increase. Tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the nation will stay at 25 percent.

On May 28, the United States Court of International Trade blocked most of the Trump administration tariffs, saying the president exceeded his authority by imposing them. To impose some of his tariffs, Trump invoked the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The court said this ‚Äúexceeds any tariff authority delegated to the President under IEEPA.‚Äù Other levies not imposed using IEEPA were not affected by the ruling. These include those on the auto industry, as well as the tariffs on steel and aluminum.

On May 29, a federal appeals court paused the block, temporarily preserving the tariffs. The move grants the judges additional time to consider the government‚Äôs appeal.

On April 29, President Trump eased the tariffs he applied on the automobile industry. While the 25 percent tariff on both imported automobiles and key automobile parts is still in effect, the president‚Äôs latest executive order lays down a mechanism to prevent other tariffs, such as those on aluminum and steel, from stacking on top of this percentage. Cars that are produced domestically with over 85 percent USCMA-compliant parts will effectively now face no tariff. He also announced car manufacturers can apply for a reimbursement to offset the tariffs on imported car parts if the car is assembled in the United States. Trump indicated, though, that the measures were temporary.

On April 9, the same day that global reciprocal tariffs were set to go into effect, President Trump announced that all countries would now face the baseline 10 percent tariff rate for 90 days. Three countries in the region‚ÄîGuyana, Venezuela, and Nicaragua‚Äîwere set to face higher tariffs but will now enjoy a lower rate until June. The one exception to Trump's policy shift is China, which is already facing a higher rate.

On April 2, President Trump announced the rates for global reciprocal tariffs. A 10 percent tariff will be imposed on all countries but some will face higher rates. The global 10 percent tariffs will go into effect on April 5, while the higher tariffs on some countries will go into effect on April 9. Neither Canada nor Mexico is on the list. For those countries, USMCA compliant goods still don't have tariffs, while non-USMCA compliant goods face a 25 percent tariff.

On March 26, President Donald Trump announced 25 percent tariffs on automobiles (passenger vehicles and light trucks) and key automobile parts imported into the United States. These tariffs will go into effect on April 3.

On March 24, President Trump signed an executive order announcing tariffs on countries that import oil from Venezuela. Starting April 2, any country that imports directly from the South American country or through a third party will face a 25 percent tariff on all goods it exports into the United States.

At midnight on March 12, the Trump administration‚Äôs universal 25 percent tariffs on aluminum and steel imports went into effect. In swift retaliation, Canada announced tariffs on U.S. goods worth over $20 billion.

On March 11, one day before 25 percent tariffs on steel and aluminum go into effect, President Trump announced he was doubling the rate for Canada. Trump also threatened to increase the tariffs on Canadian automobile parts that go into effect on April 2 if Canada doesn‚Äôt suspend selected tariffs.

On March 6, just two days after the 25 percent tariff on Mexico and Canada went into effect, President Trump paused the tariffs on goods from the two countries that fall under the USMCA agreement. The delay covers most Mexican and Canadian exports to the United States and will be in place until April 2.

On March 4, a 25 percent tariff on imports from Canada and Mexico went into effect. Canada retaliated against the United States on the same day, imposing a 25 percent tariff $155 billion worth of U.S. goods. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said in a press conference that Mexico will respond with retaliatory tariffs on Sunday, March 9.

On March 3, U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer released three documents related to President Trump‚Äôs trade agenda: the 2025 Trade Policy Agenda, the 2024 Annual Report, and a report on the World Trade Organization. The 2025 Trade Policy Agenda articulates how the Trump administration believes trade policy can create what it terms the ‚Äúproduction economy.‚Äù

On February 10, Trump announced a 25 percent tariff on aluminum and steel imported into the United States. The measures, which are expected to go into effect on March 12, will impact the hemisphere‚Äôs largest economies. Canada is the leading importer of steel into the United States, followed by Brazil and Mexico. Canada is also the main foreign source of aluminum for the United States. Argentina and Mexico are also among the 10 largest importers of aluminum.

On February 1, Trump began fulfilling his campaign promise to impose 25 percent tariffs on the United States‚Äô North American neighbors and closest trade partners, Canada and Mexico. Canada‚Äôs energy sector would face 10 percent tariffs. These tariffs were set to become effective on February 4. To impose these tariffs, Trump used the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). Both Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau responded with threats of retaliatory measures. On February 3, Trump held separate telephone conferences with Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau over the sanctions. After each, Trump delayed the sanctions for one month.

On February 3, Secretary of State Marco Rubio traveled to Panama from February 1 to 3. On February 2, Panamanian President Jos√© Ra√∫l Mulino received Rubio at the Palacio de las Garzas for a meeting. Mulino announced that he will not renew Panama‚Äôs signature in China‚Äôs Belt and Road Initiative. Mulino also offered the United States an airstrip in Darien province, a key passageway in hemispheric migration, for migrant repatriation flights.

Just hours after he was sworn in for his second term as president, Trump signed a series of executive orders. One of these executive orders was exclusively dedicated to his trade approach, titled ‚ÄúAmerica First Trade Policy.‚Äù In this executive order, Trump specifically referred to the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), instructing the U.S. Trade Representative to start the public consultation process for the 2026 review of the agreement early, as well as ‚Äúassess the [USMCA‚Äôs] impact on American workers‚Äù and ‚Äúmake recommendations regarding the United States‚Äô participation in the agreement.‚Äù The order also mentioned China, directing the U.S.

resumen:
In May, China hosted the fourth ministerial meeting of the China-Community of Latin America and Caribbean States (CELAC) Forum in Beijing. Colombia signed onto the Belt and Road Initiative. Public opinion polling showed the United States is ceding ground to China in South America.

Trade between Latin America and China exceeded $500 billion. Brazil is hoping to boost soy exports to China, potentially resulting in an additional $7 billion in profits due to President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs. In 2024, Brazil supplied more than 70 percent of China‚Äôs soy imports. Chinese state-owned agricultural conglomerate Cofco is building its largest export terminal outside China at the Port of Santos in Brazil. The state-owned enterprise expects the terminal to boost exports of Brazilian corn, sugar, and soybeans from 4.5 million tons to 14 million tons by 2026. Argentina and China signed a nonbinding agreement for China to import $900 million of soybeans, corn, and vegetable oil. Bolivia signed an agreement with China to export certain leather products to the Chinese market. Reuters reported that more than $1 billion in Venezuelan oil shipments to China were disguised as Brazilian oil over the last year to circumvent U.S. sanctions. The fourth ministerial meeting of the China-Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) Forum took place in Beijing in May. Colombian President Gustavo Petro, Brazilian President Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva (‚ÄúLula‚Äù), and Chilean President Gabriel Boric attended the forum. China sought to use the forum to project a united front with Latin American leaders that would also usher in a new ‚Äúgolden decade‚Äù of cooperation between China and the region. Chinese leader Xi Jinping announced a new ¬• 66 billion ($9.2 billion) credit line for the region, less than half of what Beijing offered during the China-CELAC Forum in 2015. Xi also pledged closer ties with Latin America through political, academic, and security exchanges. He also promised to increase imports from Latin America and encourage Chinese firms to boost investments in the region. The Chinese leader also singled out Trump without explicitly naming him by remarking that ‚Äú[b]ullying and coercion only lead to isolation.‚Äù It was also announced that five Latin American countries (Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru, and Uruguay) would receive visa exemptions for travel to China beginning June 1. Panama was not granted visa exemptions. Lula also completed a state visit in Beijing, his third meeting with Xi since Lula returned to the Brazilian presidency in 2023. He brought 11 ministers, several high-ranking politicians, and a delegation of more than 150 business leaders. The two sides signed thirty agreements, and Brazil‚Äôs trade and investment promotion agency announced that Brazil had secured $5 billion in investment by Chinese companies, including a $1 billion investment from China‚Äôs Envision Energy to produce sustainable aviation fuel in Brazil. The two countries‚Äô central banks also agreed to a R$ 157 billion ($28 billion) currency swap agreement over a five-year period. Petro signed a joint cooperation plan on the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) during his visit to Beijing. Prior to Petro‚Äôs announcement of his intention to sign on to China‚Äôs BRI, outgoing U.S. Special Envoy for Latin America Maurico Claver-Carone remarked, ‚ÄúPresident Petro‚Äôs rapprochement with China is a great opportunity for Ecuadorian roses and Central American coffee,‚Äù On May 15, the State Department announced that the United States would oppose any funds from multilateral lenders, such as the Inter-American Development Bank, for Chinese companies in Colombia and other countries in the region that have joined BRI. Colombia also petitioned to join the New Development Bank (formerly known as the BRICS Development Bank). Petro announced that Colombia could purchase $512 million worth of shares in the bank. Guyanese Foreign Minister Hugh Todd met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and the officials pledged to bolster cooperation between their two countries in energy and minerals. Ecuadorian Economy and Finance Minister Sariha Moya convened with representatives from several Chinese banks to discuss potential financing opportunities for Ecuadorian President Daniel Noboa‚Äôs initiatives in renewable energy and infrastructure.

China‚Äôs new ambassador to Guyana, Yang Yang, wrote an op-ed in the Stabroek News, highlighting that Chinese investment in Guyana has increased forty-fold between 2019 and 2024. Brazilian Planning Minister Simone Tebet announced that her government was having discussions with China about constructing a railway linking Brazil to the Port of Chancay in Peru. On May 5, Ecuadorian state-owned oil company Petroecuador inked an agreement with Chinese state-owned oil company Sinopec to drill new wells in the Orellana and Sucumb√≠os provinces. On May 7, Chile‚Äôs economic development agency announced that two Chinese companies, BYD and Tsingshan, were withdrawing from plans to build lithium cathode plants in Chile, citing declines in global lithium prices. A delegation of Chinese officials and business leaders traveled to Argentina to discuss new and expanded commercial opportunities between the two countries.

House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence Chair Rick Crawford (R-AR) and Representative Ronny Jackson (R-TX) took a trip to Barbados, Guyana, and Suriname in late April. During a meeting with Peruvian Defense Minister Walter Astudillo and Peruvian Foreign Affairs Minister Elmer Schialer, U.S. Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth stated that China posed a threat to hemispheric security. In a press conference outside his official residence, new U.S. Ambassador to Panama Kevin Cabrera remarked that his first priority was to strengthen U.S.-Panama bilateral efforts to ‚Äúcounter harmful influences in the region, such as that of China‚Äù and that ‚ÄúChina is not a good ally neither for Panama nor for our hemisphere.‚Äù The Chinese Embassy in Panama issued a statement refuting Cabrera‚Äôs claims. A few weeks later, Cabrera posted on X that he would work to ensure the Panama Canal‚Äôs neutrality and defend it ‚Äúfrom the malign influence of the Chinese Communist Party and its proxies in Panama and throughout our hemisphere.‚Äù U.S. Ambassador to Guatemala Tobin Bradley warned at a regional security conference that using Chinese technology or doing business with China carried risks for Latin American governments. In an interview with NBC News‚Äô Meet the Press, Trump repeated his claim that China took over the Panama Canal. China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce spokesperson He Yongqian warned parties involved in the sale of CK Hutchison‚Äôs Panama ports to ‚Äúproceed with caution,‚Äù as China continues to review the deal.

title: Impact of Trump‚Äôs new tariffs on steel, aluminium on U.S. economy
content: Trump threatens to increase steel tariffs to 50%, impacting U.S. economy, consumer demand, and domestic production negatively.
resumen:
Mr. Trump threatened to increase import tariffs on steel and aluminium from the current 25% to 50% from June 4.
Steel and aluminium are key basic inputs used in a wide variety of industries and economic activities.
The tariffs would further increase the domestic prices of goods and services in the U.S. where steel and aluminium are used, lower the consumer and industrial demand for such products and slow down the overall growth of the economy.
The U.S. economy had contracted by 0.2% in the first quarter of 2025 as compared to the previous quarter, while inflation had declined to 2.31% at the end of April 2025.
The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has forecast a slowing down of the U.S. GDP growth rate to 1.6% in 2025 from 2.8% in 2024 and a fall in World GDP growth rate to 2.9% for 2025 as compared to 3.3% in the previous year.
In April 2025, the U.S. economy added 1,77,000 new jobs, exceeding previous expectations, though falling short of the 2,56,000 new jobs generated in December 2024.
The unemployment rate remained steady at 4.2% April 2025.
When an import tariff is imposed on a commodity in a free-market economy following free international trade, the higher tariff-inclusive price will become the new domestic price.
It reduces the consumer‚Äôs surplus.
Governments all over the world use import tariffs as measures to increase Government revenue and to support domestic manufacturers of the import competing products for generating local employment, incomes and economic growth.
Currently automobile imports into the U.S. from the EU attract an import tariff of 25%.
With the new 50% import tariffs on steel and aluminium imports from the EU and other countries (excepting U.K.), American producers of automobiles who use steel and aluminium as inputs in their manufacturing process, will not only see a sharp rise in their manufacturing costs, but will also see the 25% import tariff on automobiles not providing the protection that it is intended to provide.
The rate of effective protection provided to Ford to ramp up the domestic production of Mustang car can be estimated using the following formula: g = {(t-a¬°t¬°) / (1-a¬°)}.
In the example, the rate of effective protection, g, can be calculated as -0.25 or -25%, which is a negative rate and acts as a disincentive for ramping up the domestic production of Ford Mustang cars.
If the import tariff on steel and aluminium metals and parts is fixed at 10%, then the rate of effective protection, g, will be 0.55 or 55%, which will be a sufficient incentive for Ford to ramp up the domestic production of its Mustang cars.

title: A long-term perspective on US tariffs
content: April 2025 marked a turning point in the dynamics of economic and trade relations between the US and the rest of the world.
resumen:
In April 2025, the US administration introduced "reciprocal tariffs" against all its trading partners, based on the trade deficit in manufactured goods. This caused shock, reviving the spectre of a trade war and weakening global growth.

The motivations behind the new tariffs are:
*   To reindustrialise the US economy and promote local jobs.
*   To create fiscal leeway to reduce corporate and household taxes.
*   To promote bilateral negotiations, excluding China.

The impact can be measured on GDP, inflation, and monetary policy. Growth will likely decline in 2025, from around 1.8 per cent in the central scenario to 1.1 per cent to 1.3 per cent in the worst-case scenario. Inflation is estimated at 1.4 percentage points, potentially reaching 4 per cent. The Fed will probably cut interest rates at least twice this year, with a consensus of around four cuts.

If a concrete agreement is reached by the end of the 90-day negotiation period it could be positive for equity markets and lead to a rebound in risk assets.

title: Trump Tariffs: What‚Äôs the Latest on the Trade War?
content: By The New York Times Since re-entering office, President Trump has announced a barrage of tariffs to try to rewire the global economy. The trade actions have taken effect in fits and starts ...
resumen:
President Trump has announced tariffs to try to rewire the global economy.

On Wednesday, Mr. Trump increased tariffs on foreign steel and aluminum, doubling them to 50 percent from 25 percent. The higher tariffs aim to counter foreign countries that offload low-priced steel and aluminum in the United States market. The higher tariff rate is likely to raise costs for American businesses that rely on steel and aluminum and could result in some consumer goods getting more expensive. Doubling the tariff is also likely to further upset countries that export metals, including Canada.

Many of Mr. Trump‚Äôs other tariffs are tied up in a legal back-and-forth. A federal judicial panel ruled that many of his large-scale tariffs were issued illegally, including those targeting China, Canada and Mexico. A federal appeals court temporarily preserved many of the levies. The judicial panel‚Äôs ruling, which does not affect the tariffs on steel, would have forced a wind-down of tariffs Mr. Trump had enacted under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, a 1977 law. Thursday‚Äôs appellate decision is temporary and does not end the legal matter.

In April, Mr. Trump rolled out tariffs on nearly 60 U.S. trading partners before abruptly reversing course for 90 days for every country except China. On May 12, he temporarily paused the China tariffs. On Friday, he appeared to revive his global trade war by threatening steeper tariffs on the European Union; by Sunday, he had backed down.

The United States and China on May 12 said they had reached an agreement to reduce the tariffs they have imposed on each other for 90 days while they try to negotiate a trade deal. Many Chinese imports entering the United States had been subject to at least a 145 percent tariff, which was dropped to 30 percent. China agreed to lower the tariffs it had put on imports from the United States to 10 percent, down from 125 percent. Separately, Mr. Trump eliminated a longstanding exception that allowed many relatively inexpensive goods from China to enter the country duty free. Such imports now face a 54 percent tariff or a $100 flat fee. On Friday, Mr. Trump suggested that the truce between the United States and China was not holding.

Mr. Trump also recently targeted the chief executive of Apple, Tim Cook. He said in late May that he had told Mr. Cook he expected iPhones sold in the United States to be ‚Äúmanufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else‚Äù or face a 25 percent tariff.

On May 25, Mr. Trump said he would delay a 50 percent tariff on goods from the European Union until July 9. A couple days earlier, he said that discussions with the European Union were ‚Äúgoing nowhere‚Äù and that steep tariffs would take effect in a week.

Last month, Mr. Trump imposed the same 10 percent tariff on Britain that he put on other countries. Cars shipped to the United States from Britain face a 27.5 percent tariff, and British steel is subjected to an import duty of 25 percent. In early May, Mr. Trump unveiled a preliminary agreement with Britain that would pare back these tariffs. Under the terms of the deal, Britain would be allowed to send 100,000 vehicles to the United States under a tariff of 10 percent, and U.S. tariffs on steel would fall to zero. In the meantime, U.S. imports of British steel and aluminum would be spared from the doubling of tariffs Mr. Trump announced in June. The 10 percent levy in place for all British exports would remain in place.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs point of view appears to be that any trade deficit is bad. The president and his advisers say their goal is to make the tariffs so painful that they force companies to make their products in the United States. Mr. Trump has also described tariffs as a tool that will force Canada, Mexico and China to crack down on the flow of drugs and migrants coming into the United States. The president also maintains that tariffs will rake in huge sums of revenue that the government can use to pay for domestic tax cuts.

A tariff is a government surcharge on products imported from other countries. Tariffs are paid by the companies that import the goods. The revenue from U.S. tariffs is paid by U.S. importers to the U.S. Treasury Department.

Walmart could try to force the cost onto the Vietnamese shoe manufacturer, cut into its own profit margins and absorb the cost of the tariff, raise the price of the shoes at its stores, or some combination of the above. Earlier in May, Walmart‚Äôs chief executive cautioned that tariffs would push the company to start raising prices soon, and refrained from projecting profits for its current quarter. Mr. Trump, in turn, scolded the retailer on social media, telling it to ‚ÄúEAT THE TARIFFS‚Äù and keep prices down.

Toy makers, children‚Äôs shops and specialty retailers have recently begun pausing orders for the winter holidays. Mattel, the U.S. toy company and maker of Barbies, recently said it would raise prices on U.S. toys because of Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs on imports from China.

For American families, the full effect of the new policies is still to come, but they are likely to result in higher prices at grocery stores, car dealerships, electronics retailers and clothing outlets.

title: Trump Trade War Triggers Sharp Decline in US Dollar on Tariff Escalation
content: The Trump trade war has triggered strong selling pressure in the US Dollar, pushing Gold, EUR/USD and AUD/USD higher, while USD/CHF hovers on the edge of a long-term breakdown.
resumen:
The Trump trade war has triggered strong selling pressure in the US Dollar, pushing Gold, EUR/USD and AUD/USD higher, while USD/CHF hovers on the edge of a long-term breakdown.

US President Donald Trump announced new tariff actions on imported steel and aluminium on Friday. He stated that the tariffs could double to 50% starting Wednesday, June 4, 2025. This move reignites tensions with key US trading partners, including China, South Korea, and Vietnam. The announcement triggered an immediate market reaction. On Monday, shares of steelmakers in South Korea and Vietnam dropped sharply. The tariffs are raising fears of a broader trade war. Trump stated that China had failed to honour a critical minerals agreement. In response, China‚Äôs Commerce Ministry called the claim ‚Äúgroundless‚Äù and vowed to take forceful measures. Moreover, Trump‚Äôs tariff policy has already faced legal challenges. A US trade court blocked some measures last week, citing executive overreach. However, an appeals court reinstated the tariffs the following day. The Trump administration also signalled its intention to pursue alternative legal channels to enforce the levies.

Following the announcement of new tariffs on steel and aluminium, the dollar resumed its decline. This decline has pushed the dollar lower against other major currencies. EUR/USD has increased to $1.1450, GBP/USD to $1.3555, and AUD/USD to $0.65, while NZD/USD has increased to $0.6050. On the other hand, gold (XAU/USD) has broken the key level of $3,360 on strong safe haven demand.

Doubling tariffs on steel and aluminium could slow growth and fuel inflation. The US dollar has struggled and remains uncertain due to sudden shifts in tariff policy throughout 2025. Investors are increasingly uneasy about the rising US deficit. Trump‚Äôs proposed tax and spending bill would add $3.8 trillion to the existing $36.2 trillion federal debt over the next decade. This has fueled a broad ‚ÄúSell America‚Äù sentiment across stocks, bonds, and the dollar.

The National Financial Conditions Index has dropped to -0.606, indicating a shift toward monetary easing. If the impact of COVID-19 is removed, the University of Michigan‚Äôs index of current economic conditions has fallen close to its lowest level since records began in 1960. Continued unemployment claims rose to 1.92 million on May 17. The unemployment rate remains at 4.2%.

The economic uncertainty triggered by the high tariffs has significantly impacted the US Dollar Index. The index has broken the long-term support at 100.65 and moved toward the 96‚Äì98 region. The monthly close below 100.65 indicates continued bearish pressure. A break below 96 could trigger a decline toward the long-term support at 90.

The long-term breakdown in the US Dollar Index has also caused USD/CHF to break the key support level of $0.83. This breakdown has opened the door for a potential long-term move toward the $0.71 level. The shadow at the monthly candle of May 2025 indicates bearish pressure.

The breakdown in the US Dollar Index has pushed EUR/USD above $1.12. A breakout from $1.12 has opened the door for a move toward $1.22. If the US Dollar Index breaks below 96 and moves toward 90, it could drive EUR/USD further toward the $1.22 region.

Last year, Republicans on the U.S. House Agriculture Committee, with the support of Kansas Rep. Tracey Mann, wrote a Farm Bill that went nowhere. The Senate Ag Committee didn‚Äôt even write a bill. Congress missed its second deadline to extend the 2018 Farm Bill.

content: Until the trade dispute between China and the US is fully resolved, there‚Äôs always going the be the danger of higher tariffs hanging over the markets. Investors can probably ignore this risk if China ...
resumen: Tariff uncertainty remains elevated despite trade truce. The wait for new trade deals seems to be getting longer. Trump introduced 10% universal tariffs on most imports into the United States, and sectoral tariffs on steel, aluminium and cars. Reciprocal tariffs will be revisited on July 9, with those on China suspended until August 12. Trump just announced the doubling of the tariffs on steel and aluminium to a staggering 50%. Investors have maintained the optimism that returned to the markets when Trump delayed the reciprocal tariffs. The Trump administration is serious about rebalancing trade. Trade negotiations can be a very lengthy process. Britain seems to have caved in to Trump‚Äôs demands quite quickly. A deal with Japan and India could be near. The current 90-day extensions will be extended further, at least for the big countries/blocs such as the EU. The Fed has been in wait-and-see mode for much of the year to assess the impact of Trump‚Äôs policies on inflation and the labour market. The US dollar has fallen by about 9% against a basket of currencies in the year-to-date. One-month implied volatility rates for EUR/USD and USD/JPY have not declined as much as the VIX has since the April spike. Gold has rallied by more than 25% so far in 2025 and it‚Äôs approaching its record high from April. A successful outcome of the trade war hinges on a US-China pact. Talks between the two sides appear to have stalled, although there‚Äôs reports that Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are planning on holding a phone call as early as this week. Markets are potentially staring at protracted negotiations that last well beyond the summer, with the risk of stretching into 2026. The average tariff rate doesn‚Äôt exceed 10%, then the impact on inflation will be limited and temporary. The President‚Äôs threat to tax Apple if the company doesn‚Äôt shift production of all its US-bound iPhones to America is an example of how far he is willing to go to achieve his objectives. The risk of re-escalation remains too high, and there‚Äôs also Congress‚Äôs budget reconciliation bill to consider that could raise the national debt to unsustainable levels.

title: Canadian economy will be among those hit hardest by global slowdown, says OECD
content: Global economic growth is slowing more than was expected only a few months ago as the fallout from the Trump administration's trade war continues, the OECD said Tuesday. And Canada is among the ...
resumen:
Global economic growth is slowing more than was expected only a few months ago as the fallout from the Trump administration's trade war continues, the OECD said on Tuesday, and Canada is among the countries where the downturn is most concentrated.

The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) revised down its outlook, trimming its estimates from March for growth of 3.1 per cent this year and 3.0 per cent next year.

The global economy is on course to slow from 3.3 per cent last year to 2.9 per cent in 2025 and 2026.

The slowdown is concentrated in the United States, Canada, Mexico and China, with other economies expected to see smaller downward adjustments.

The growth outlook would likely be even weaker if protectionism increases, further fuelling inflation, disrupting supply chains and rattling financial markets.

Additional increases in trade barriers or prolonged policy uncertainty would further lower growth prospects and likely push inflation higher in countries imposing tariffs.

OECD Secretary General Mathias Cormann said if Washington raised bilateral tariffs by an additional 10 percentage points on all countries, as compared with the rates in force as of mid-May, global economic output would be about 0.3 per cent lower after two years.

The OECD projects that Canada's economic growth will slow from 1.5 per cent in 2024 to 1.0 per cent in 2025 and 1.1 per cent in 2026 because of trade tensions with the U.S., long its largest export market.

The organization also expects that business investment and exports will decline this year, and that a weak labour market will weigh on Canadian households' spending behaviour.

Headline inflation will tick up slightly, though the impact of higher tariffs on consumer prices will be partly offset by lower gas prices, which the organization attributes to the end of the consumer carbon tax.

Core inflation will increase "for a period," before coming back down toward the central bank's two per cent target next year.

Inflationary pressures from higher tariffs will require a more cautious approach to lowering interest rates.

The rate currently sits at 2.75 per cent, with the bank's next meeting set for Wednesday.

Increased government spending, particularly on housing affordability and new social programs, has recently worsened the general government balance, although it had previously been in surplus.

The OECD forecast the U.S. economy would grow only 1.6 per cent this year and 1.5 per cent next year, assuming for the purpose of making calculations that tariffs in place mid-May would remain so through the rest of 2025 and 2026.

For 2025, the new forecast marked a sizable cut, as the organization had previously expected the world's biggest economy would grow 2.2 per cent this year and 1.6 per cent next year.

While new tariffs may create incentives to manufacture in the United States, higher import prices would squeeze consumers' purchasing power and economic policy uncertainty would hold back corporate investment, the OECD warned.

Trump's sweeping tax cut and spending bill was expected to push the U.S. budget deficit to eight per cent of economic output by 2026.

As tariffs fuel inflation pressures, the U.S. Federal Reserve was seen keeping rates on hold through this year and then cutting the fed funds rate to 3.25 to 3.5 per cent by the end of 2026.

In China, the fallout from the U.S. tariff hikes would be partly offset by government subsidies for a trade-in program on consumer goods like mobile phones and appliances and increased welfare transfers, the OECD said.

It estimated the world's second-biggest economy, which is not an OECD member, would grow 4.7 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent in 2026, little changed from previous forecasts for 4.8 per cent in 2025 and 4.4 per cent in 2026.

The outlook for the euro area was unchanged from March, with growth forecast this year at 1.0 per cent and 1.2 per cent next year, boosted by resilient labour markets and interest rate cuts, while more public spending from Germany would buoy 2026 growth.

title: Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Expected to Drag Down the Global Economy
content: Economic growth will slow this year and next as the trade war hampers development in the United States and around the world, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.
resumen:
President Trump‚Äôs trade war is expected to slow growth in the world‚Äôs leading economies, including the United States, this year and in the years to come, unless world leaders can resolve their differences over trade.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development slashed its outlook for global output to 2.9 percent this year, from 3.3 percent in 2024, the organization said in its economic report released on Tuesday.

Economic growth in the United States is expected to be particularly weak, the organization said, rising 1.6 percent this year, a drop from the 2.2 percent projected in March, and 1.5 percent in 2026, down from its previous estimate of 1.6 percent. The U.S. economy grew 2.8 percent in 2024.

In the first three months of the year, economic growth in the countries monitored by the organization, which is based in Paris, ‚Äúdropped abruptly‚Äù to 0.1 percent from the last three months of 2024, which is ‚Äúthe slowest rate of growth since the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic some five years ago,‚Äù Mr. Cormann said.

Since taking office, Mr. Trump has imposed tariffs, then halted them for several weeks, then reinstated some, in the hopes of winning new trade deals from once-close allies like Canada, Mexico and the European Union, as well as longtime rivals like China.

Even if the Trump administration increases tariffs on most of America‚Äôs trading partners by just 10 percent, it would shave 1.6 percent off economic growth in the country over two years, the report said. Growth on a global scale would contract nearly a full percentage point in the same period.

The economies of the 20 countries using the common euro currency are projected to grow 1 percent in 2025 and 1.2 percent in 2026, in line with the O.E.C.D. forecast from March. China‚Äôs economy is expected to see 4.7 percent growth this year and 4.3 percent in 2026, down 0.1 percentage points from the organization‚Äôs spring projection.

Economists in the organization urged countries to reach agreements on trade and to increase investment to revive economic growth.

‚ÄúOur key recommendation, to all governments, is to engage with each other to address issues in a global trading system cooperatively,‚Äù Mr. Cormann said.

title: Why are people calling Trump TACO, what is the Trump Collar? Here's what it all means
content: President Donald Trump erupts over TACO trade question. Here's what the TACO nickname means and what is a Trump Collar.
resumen:
President Donald Trump's trade war tactics have earned him a new nickname "TACO". The new acronym is gaining popularity among Wall Street investors.

The term TACO, which stands for "Trump Always Chickens Out.‚Äù First coined by Financial Times commentator Robert Armstrong to describe what he says is Trump‚Äôs pattern of announcing heavy tariffs on countries causing economic shock, panic and stock market hits and then later reversing course with pauses or reductions that create a market rebound.

When asked about TACO on Wednesday by a reporter, Trump responded, ‚ÄúI chicken out? Oh, I‚Äôve never heard that. You mean because I reduced China from 145% that I set down to 100... and then to another number?‚Äù He went on to defend his decisions to slash his tariffs on China for the next 90 days and extend his deadline for a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union until July 9.

Trump said "because I gave the European Union a 50% tax tariff, and they called up and they said 'please lets meet right now, please let's meet right now,' and I said OK, I'll give you until July." He then clarified that they weren't willing to meet initially, "And after I did what I did, they said, 'we'll meet anytime you want.' You call that chickening out?"

After the reporter's TACO question and Trump's heated response, taco and chicken related memes went viral, including an old Cinco de Mayo tweet by the President himself.

As "TACO" Trump gained popularity, Nomura's strategist Charlie McElligott came up with "Trump Collar" in the same vein. In finance, a collar is a risk management strategy for stock owners that protects from big losses but also limits gains ‚Äî creating a range within which the stock's price can fluctuate without significant profit or loss.

McElligott likened the collar term to how the stock market reacts to Trump. It may want to go up, but Trump's random social media posts and trade-tariff remarks can make the market nervous and therefor volatile.

‚ÄúYou all know ‚ÄòArt of the Deal‚Äô Trump ‚Ä¶ and over the past month+, the ‚ÄòTACO‚Äô-kind ‚Ä¶ but what it all adds up to now is the de facto ‚ÄòTrump Collar,‚Äô as the market retrains the reaction function in the ‚ÄòHuman VVIX‚Äô era,‚Äù said McElligott according to MarketWatch.

title: 5Trump Rails Against Court Rulings Blocking His Tariffs,...
content: President Donald Trump claimed losing legal challenges to his sweeping tariffs would lead to the "economic ruination" of America after federal courts blocked his emergency trade powers while an ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump claimed losing legal challenges to his sweeping tariffs would lead to the ‚Äúeconomic ruination‚Äù of America.

Trump warned on Truth Social Sunday that adverse court rulings ‚Äúwould allow other Countries to hold our Nation hostage with their anti-American Tariffs,‚Äù following the U.S. Court of International Trade‚Äôs unanimous decision blocking emergency import taxes.

The U.S. Court of International Trade ruled unanimously to block Trump‚Äôs use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose tariffs.

Judges appointed by Trump, Barack Obama, and Ronald Reagan said the administration overstepped constitutional limits.

U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras issued a separate ruling blocking emergency tariff powers, writing in a 33-page document that IEEPA ‚Äúdoes not grant Trump the authority to impose or adjust tariffs without approval from Congress.‚Äù

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted a temporary stay on Thursday, delaying the lower court‚Äôs ruling.

Trump administration lawyers have until June 9 to file their response.

Reciprocal tariffs announced April 2 remain in legal limbo.

The blocked tariffs include 10% across-the-board duties, 20% on Chinese imports, and 25% on non-USMCA goods from Canada and Mexico, potentially generating $200 billion annually.

Goldman Sachs analysts noted Trump could reimpose similar tariffs ‚Äúwithin days‚Äù using Section 122 trade law, which allows 15% tariffs for 150 days without congressional approval.

The S&P 500 rose 0.6% Thursday following the court decision.

Cato Institute economist Scott Lincicome said import-dependent sectors rallied on relief from ‚Äúpotentially crippling new costs.‚Äù

The original tariff announcement in April triggered a $5 trillion market capitalization loss over two days.

title: China hits back on Trump claims as trade war reignites
content: China hit back Monday on President Donald Trump‚Äôs claims the Asian country was in breach of a new trade agreement, countering that the U.S. itself was undermining the deal with new sanctions.
resumen:
China hit back Monday, July 2, on President Donald Trump‚Äôs claims the Asian country was in breach of a new trade agreement, countering that the U.S. itself was undermining the deal with new sanctions.
The new rift was dragging down U.S. stock indexes Monday morning and threatens to reignite a Sino-U.S. trade war that had cooled somewhat following high-level trade talks that led to a temporary agreement last month.
A statement from China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce released Monday said Trump administration actions ‚Äúseriously undermine the existing consensus reached at the Geneva economic and trade talks, and seriously damage China‚Äôs legitimate rights and interests.‚Äù
Chinese officials also pointed to recent signaling from the U.S. about potential new regulations for advanced microchips and the revocation of U.S. visas for Chinese students, per CBS News, as evidence that the U.S. was acting in bad faith following the trade deal.
A White House official told CNBC that Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are likely to speak this week.
In Truth Social post last Friday, Trump said that the deal had led to greater economic stability for China and ‚Äúeverybody was happy‚Äù but alluded to China violating terms of the agreement.
Trump wrote: ‚ÄúThe bad news is that China, perhaps not surprisingly to some, HAS TOTALLY VIOLATED ITS AGREEMENT WITH US. So much for being Mr. NICE GUY!‚Äù
Trump‚Äôs social media post last Friday morning offered no details about the nature of China‚Äôs alleged breach, later reporting indicated the president‚Äôs issue was focused on China‚Äôs export rules on rare earth minerals.
China controls 90% of the world‚Äôs rare earth elements production capacity and, according to the U.S. Department of Energy, the minerals play a critical role in U.S. national security, energy independence and economic growth.
In a deal announced May 12, both countries agreed to roll back reciprocal tariffs to a 10% rate for a 90-day period beginning May 14.
Other, sector-specific U.S. trade levies on steel, aluminum and automobiles remained in place, as did a 20% tariff Trump announced earlier this year to address fentanyl trafficking.
The announcement followed two days of meetings in Geneva between Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer with a delegation of Chinese officials.
Trump, at the time, lauded the deal as ‚Äúhistoric.‚Äù
Trade traffic between the countries was upended in April when a series of retaliatory tariffs drove levies to 145% on Chinese imports and 125% on U.S. exports to China.
At a rally in Pennsylvania last Friday, Trump announced plans to raise a sector-specific tariff on steel imports from 25% to 50%.
In a ruling issued last Wednesday, the U.S. Court of International Trade struck down a wide swath of trade tariff decrees made by Trump since he took office.
A day later, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted a temporary hold on the lower court ruling.
The plaintiffs in the lower court case have until June 5 to respond to the stay decision and Trump‚Äôs legal team will have until June 9 to develop its argument for the pause to remain in place as the appeals process plays out.
The trade court ruling, should it stand, impacts new tariffs Trump has issued, without congressional approval, under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

In the last week, the winds of change have calmed a bit on what has been a tumultuous sea of tariffs over the last four months. The Trump Administration has announced no new tariff measures, and no new investigations of imports have been launched by the USTR or Commerce Department. President Trump said on Friday, May 16, that the U.S. would not be able to negotiate deals for lower tariffs with each of the countries that were subject to country-specific tariff rates before the 90-day pause on the reciprocal tariffs expires on July 8. The Secretaries of Commerce and Treasury will be directly informing U.S. trading partners of their new country-specific tariff rates. The comment period for the Commerce Department‚Äôs Section 232 Investigation on imports of commercial aircraft and jet engines, and parts for commercial aircraft and jet engines remains open until June 3, 2025.

Here is the developing landscape of U.S. tariffs as of May 21, 2025:

*   **Global:** Reciprocal tariffs ‚Äì 10% ad valorem duty. China-specific 54% ad valorem duty on de minimis valued imports, other country-specific duties suspended. Certain goods excluded. Revised 5/12/2025. Implemented 4/2/2025.
*   **China:** Chinese Vessels ‚Äì Port Entry Fees on Chinese owned or built vessels, and foreign-built car carriers. Implemented: 4/17/2025.
*   **Global:** Automobiles ‚Äì 25% ad valorem duty on imports of automobiles (with certain allowances for USMCA-qualifying autos) and certain automobile parts (with limited tariff offsets). Implemented 4/3/2025 (effective 5/3/2025 for automobile parts).
*   **Global:** All goods imported from any country that imports Venezuelan oil ‚Äì discretionary 25% ad valorem duty may be imposed. Implemented 4/2/2025.

*   **Global:** Aluminum ‚Äì 25% ad valorem duty on imports of aluminum articles and derivative products with no exemptions or exclusions. Implemented: 3/12/2025.
*   **Canada:** 10% ad valorem duty on non-USMCA-qualifying energy and potash. 25% ad valorem duty on all other non-USMCA-qualifying products of Canada. Implemented: 3/4/2025; 4/2/2025 (updated).
*   **Mexico:** 25% ad valorem duty on all non-USMCA-qualifying products of Mexico. Implemented: 3/4/2025; 4/2/2025 (updated).
*   **China:** 20% ad valorem duty on all products of China. Implemented: 3/4/2025.

title: Carney won't reveal spending plans, enraging critics ‚Äî but some call it savvy
content: The government is defending its decision not to issue a spring budget by pointing to the uncertain economic situation. While not all critics accept that framing, some say there could be some benefits ...
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney won't release a federal budget before fall, which would mean over a year since the government released one, an unprecedented gap (outside of 2020).
Interim Conservative leader Andrew Scheer and others in his party asked the budget question repeatedly.
Carney pointed out that Pierre Polievre‚Äôs 100-day plan announced during the election hadn‚Äôt included a budget either.
Carney and his finance minister, Fran√ßois-Philippe Champagne, took turns repeating the great news that they were delivering a tax cut and breaking down provincial trade barriers.
Carney gave reporters the closest thing he‚Äôs given to an explanation for skipping the spring budget in Rome: ‚ÄúThere's not much value in trying to rush through a budget in a very narrow window ‚Äî three weeks ‚Äî with a new cabinet [and] effectively a new finance minister," he said. "We will have a much more comprehensive, effective, ambitious, prudent budget in the fall.‚Äù
In an interview with Power and Politics, Carney said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a fan of picking an arbitrary number and then figuring out how to spend up to it,‚Äù after describing a host of uncertainties looming over Canada‚Äôs defence budget. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one of the reasons we will have a fall budget, not a budget tomorrow.‚Äù
NDP MP Heather McPherson said that it‚Äôs baffling why Carney invited such a storm.
Finance minister Champagne told Politico that the reason Liberals are waiting until fall is they want to have ‚Äúmore clarity around defense, around the trade war that is happening now in the world,‚Äù referring to tariffs and the upcoming NATO meeting where Canada‚Äôs defence budget is almost certain to rise dramatically.
Champagne said the government is also waiting to get ‚Äúinitial feedback from our initiatives on government efficiency.‚Äù
Michael Wernick, former Clerk of the Privy Council, doesn't believe the delay affects the business of the government and may improve scrutiny from parliament.
Wernick said: ‚ÄúIn practical or operational terms, the four-month delay really doesn't matter.‚Äù
Wernick said: ‚ÄúThe practice of having a big, beautiful budget, chock full of just about everything the government wants to do in the coming year and hundreds of pages of implementation legislation covering everything from A to Z, is a fairly recent practice.‚Äù
The day-to-day business of a government doesn‚Äôt depend on a budget.
One example is the 1 per cent tax cut Carney has promised to Canadians in the lowest income bracket.
Over the past two decades, Wernick explained, governments of both parties have tended to jam their entire year‚Äôs goals into a single budget.
Ian Lee, an associate professor in the Spratt School of Business at Carleton University, said that it reduces transparency and confidence in the government.
Christopher Ragan, founding director of the Max Bell School of Public Policy, said that if you want a well-informed debate about spending, especially in the world of a minority government, we should probably know what the books look like.
Michael Wernick said: ‚ÄúThe Department of Finance puts out something called the fiscal monitor every month.‚Äù
Michael Wernick said that if parliament wants more recent or granular information, they just call the minister of finance in front of the finance committee.
Heather McPherson said that the advantage for them is they don't want to have a bad budget that they have to go out on the barbecue scene with.
Ian Lee said that Carney‚Äôs strategic objective is to buy himself a little bit of time.
Michael Wernick takes what Carney said in Rome, and what Champagne told Politico, at face value.
A press secretary told that the best bet for a concise quote from Carney is his Rome statement.
